20   A collection of basic statistical functions for Python.

22   References

25      Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New 
26      York. 2000. 
27

106             'rankdata', 'combine_pvalues', 'quantile_test',

109             'expectile', 'lmoment']

111  
112  def _chk_asarray(a, axis, *, xp=None):
113      if xp is None:
114          xp = array_namespace(a)
115  
116      if axis is None:
117          a = xp.reshape(a, (-1,))
118          outaxis = 0
119      else:
120          a = xp.asarray(a)
121          outaxis = axis
122  
123      if a.ndim == 0:
124          a = xp.reshape(a, (-1,))
125  
126      return a, outaxis
127  
128  
129  def _chk2_asarray(a, b, axis):
130      if axis is None:
131          a = np.ravel(a)
132          b = np.ravel(b)
133          outaxis = 0
134      else:
135          a = np.asarray(a)
136          b = np.asarray(b)
137          outaxis = axis
138  
139      if a.ndim == 0:
140          a = np.atleast_1d(a)
141      if b.ndim == 0:
142          b = np.atleast_1d(b)
143  
144      return a, b, outaxis
145  
146  
147  def _convert_common_float(*arrays, xp=None):
148      xp = array_namespace(*arrays) if xp is None else xp
149      arrays = [_asarray(array, subok=True) for array in arrays]
150      dtypes = [(xp.asarray(1.).dtype if xp.isdtype(array.dtype, 'integral')
151                 else array.dtype) for array in arrays]
152      dtype = xp.result_type(*dtypes)
153      arrays = [xp.astype(array, dtype, copy=False) for array in arrays]
154      return arrays[0] if len(arrays)==1 else tuple(arrays)
155  
156  
157  SignificanceResult = _make_tuple_bunch('SignificanceResult',
158                                         ['statistic', 'pvalue'], [])
159  
160  
161  # note that `weights` are paired with `x`
162  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
163          lambda x: x, n_samples=1, n_outputs=1, too_small=0, paired=True,
164          result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,), kwd_samples=['weights'])
165  def gmean(a, axis=0, dtype=None, weights=None):
166      r"""Compute the weighted geometric mean along the specified axis. 
167   
168      The weighted geometric mean of the array :math:`a_i` associated to weights 
169      :math:`w_i` is: 
170   
171      .. math:: 
172   
173          \exp \left( \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^n w_i \ln a_i }{ \sum_{i=1}^n w_i } 
174                     \right) \, , 
175   
176      and, with equal weights, it gives: 
177   
178      .. math:: 
179   
180          \sqrt[n]{ \prod_{i=1}^n a_i } \, . 
181   
182      Parameters 
183      ---------- 
184      a : array_like 
185          Input array or object that can be converted to an array. 
186      axis : int or None, optional 
187          Axis along which the geometric mean is computed. Default is 0. 
188          If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
189      dtype : dtype, optional 
190          Type to which the input arrays are cast before the calculation is 
191          performed. 
192      weights : array_like, optional 
193          The `weights` array must be broadcastable to the same shape as `a`. 
194          Default is None, which gives each value a weight of 1.0. 
195   
196      Returns 
197      ------- 
198      gmean : ndarray 
199          See `dtype` parameter above. 
200   
201      See Also 
202      -------- 
203      numpy.mean : Arithmetic average 
204      numpy.average : Weighted average 
205      hmean : Harmonic mean 
206   
207      Notes 
208      ----- 
209      The sample geometric mean is the exponential of the mean of the natural 
210      logarithms of the observations. 
211      Negative observations will produce NaNs in the output because the *natural* 
212      logarithm (as opposed to the *complex* logarithm) is defined only for 
213      non-negative reals. 
214   
215      References 
216      ---------- 
217      .. [1] "Weighted Geometric Mean", *Wikipedia*, 
218             https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_geometric_mean. 
219      .. [2] Grossman, J., Grossman, M., Katz, R., "Averages: A New Approach", 
220             Archimedes Foundation, 1983 
221   
222      Examples 
223      -------- 
224      >>> from scipy.stats import gmean 
225      >>> gmean([1, 4]) 
226      2.0 
227      >>> gmean([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) 
228      3.3800151591412964 
229      >>> gmean([1, 4, 7], weights=[3, 1, 3]) 
230      2.80668351922014 
231   
232      """
233      xp = array_namespace(a, weights)
234      a = xp.asarray(a, dtype=dtype)
235  
236      if weights is not None:
237          weights = xp.asarray(weights, dtype=dtype)
238  
239      with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
240          log_a = xp.log(a)
241  
242      return xp.exp(_xp_mean(log_a, axis=axis, weights=weights))
243  
244  
245  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
246          lambda x: x, n_samples=1, n_outputs=1, too_small=0, paired=True,
247          result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,), kwd_samples=['weights'])
248  def hmean(a, axis=0, dtype=None, *, weights=None):
249      r"""Calculate the weighted harmonic mean along the specified axis. 
250   
251      The weighted harmonic mean of the array :math:`a_i` associated to weights 
252      :math:`w_i` is: 
253   
254      .. math:: 
255   
256          \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^n w_i }{ \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{w_i}{a_i} } \, , 
257   
258      and, with equal weights, it gives: 
259   
260      .. math:: 
261   
262          \frac{ n }{ \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{a_i} } \, . 
263   
264      Parameters 
265      ---------- 
266      a : array_like 
267          Input array, masked array or object that can be converted to an array. 
268      axis : int or None, optional 
269          Axis along which the harmonic mean is computed. Default is 0. 
270          If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
271      dtype : dtype, optional 
272          Type of the returned array and of the accumulator in which the 
273          elements are summed. If `dtype` is not specified, it defaults to the 
274          dtype of `a`, unless `a` has an integer `dtype` with a precision less 
275          than that of the default platform integer. In that case, the default 
276          platform integer is used. 
277      weights : array_like, optional 
278          The weights array can either be 1-D (in which case its length must be 
279          the size of `a` along the given `axis`) or of the same shape as `a`. 
280          Default is None, which gives each value a weight of 1.0. 
281   
282          .. versionadded:: 1.9 
283   
284      Returns 
285      ------- 
286      hmean : ndarray 
287          See `dtype` parameter above. 
288   
289      See Also 
290      -------- 
291      numpy.mean : Arithmetic average 
292      numpy.average : Weighted average 
293      gmean : Geometric mean 
294   
295      Notes 
296      ----- 
297      The sample harmonic mean is the reciprocal of the mean of the reciprocals 
298      of the observations. 
299   
300      The harmonic mean is computed over a single dimension of the input 
301      array, axis=0 by default, or all values in the array if axis=None. 
302      float64 intermediate and return values are used for integer inputs. 
303   
304      The harmonic mean is only defined if all observations are non-negative; 
305      otherwise, the result is NaN. 
306   
307      References 
308      ---------- 
309      .. [1] "Weighted Harmonic Mean", *Wikipedia*, 
310             https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmonic_mean#Weighted_harmonic_mean 
311      .. [2] Ferger, F., "The nature and use of the harmonic mean", Journal of 
312             the American Statistical Association, vol. 26, pp. 36-40, 1931 
313   
314      Examples 
315      -------- 
316      >>> from scipy.stats import hmean 
317      >>> hmean([1, 4]) 
318      1.6000000000000001 
319      >>> hmean([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) 
320      2.6997245179063363 
321      >>> hmean([1, 4, 7], weights=[3, 1, 3]) 
322      1.9029126213592233 
323   
324      """
325      xp = array_namespace(a, weights)
326      a = xp.asarray(a, dtype=dtype)
327  
328      if weights is not None:
329          weights = xp.asarray(weights, dtype=dtype)
330  
331      negative_mask = a < 0
332      if xp.any(negative_mask):
333          # `where` avoids having to be careful about dtypes and will work with
334          # JAX. This is the exceptional case, so it's OK to be a little slower.
335          # Won't work for array_api_strict for now, but see data-apis/array-api#807
336          a = xp.where(negative_mask, xp.nan, a)
337          message = ("The harmonic mean is only defined if all elements are "
338                     "non-negative; otherwise, the result is NaN.")
339          warnings.warn(message, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=2)
340  
341      with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
342          return 1.0 / _xp_mean(1.0 / a, axis=axis, weights=weights)
343  
344  
345  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
346          lambda x: x, n_samples=1, n_outputs=1, too_small=0, paired=True,
347          result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,), kwd_samples=['weights'])
348  def pmean(a, p, *, axis=0, dtype=None, weights=None):
349      r"""Calculate the weighted power mean along the specified axis. 
350   
351      The weighted power mean of the array :math:`a_i` associated to weights 
352      :math:`w_i` is: 
353   
354      .. math:: 
355   
356          \left( \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^n w_i a_i^p }{ \sum_{i=1}^n w_i } 
357                \right)^{ 1 / p } \, , 
358   
359      and, with equal weights, it gives: 
360   
361      .. math:: 
362   
363          \left( \frac{ 1 }{ n } \sum_{i=1}^n a_i^p \right)^{ 1 / p }  \, . 
364   
365      When ``p=0``, it returns the geometric mean. 
366   
367      This mean is also called generalized mean or Hölder mean, and must not be 
368      confused with the Kolmogorov generalized mean, also called 
369      quasi-arithmetic mean or generalized f-mean [3]_. 
370   
371      Parameters 
372      ---------- 
373      a : array_like 
374          Input array, masked array or object that can be converted to an array. 
375      p : int or float 
376          Exponent. 
377      axis : int or None, optional 
378          Axis along which the power mean is computed. Default is 0. 
379          If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
380      dtype : dtype, optional 
381          Type of the returned array and of the accumulator in which the 
382          elements are summed. If `dtype` is not specified, it defaults to the 
383          dtype of `a`, unless `a` has an integer `dtype` with a precision less 
384          than that of the default platform integer. In that case, the default 
385          platform integer is used. 
386      weights : array_like, optional 
387          The weights array can either be 1-D (in which case its length must be 
388          the size of `a` along the given `axis`) or of the same shape as `a`. 
389          Default is None, which gives each value a weight of 1.0. 
390   
391      Returns 
392      ------- 
393      pmean : ndarray, see `dtype` parameter above. 
394          Output array containing the power mean values. 
395   
396      See Also 
397      -------- 
398      numpy.average : Weighted average 
399      gmean : Geometric mean 
400      hmean : Harmonic mean 
401   
402      Notes 
403      ----- 
404      The power mean is computed over a single dimension of the input 
405      array, ``axis=0`` by default, or all values in the array if ``axis=None``. 
406      float64 intermediate and return values are used for integer inputs. 
407   
408      The power mean is only defined if all observations are non-negative; 
409      otherwise, the result is NaN. 
410   
411      .. versionadded:: 1.9 
412   
413      References 
414      ---------- 
415      .. [1] "Generalized Mean", *Wikipedia*, 
416             https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_mean 
417      .. [2] Norris, N., "Convexity properties of generalized mean value 
418             functions", The Annals of Mathematical Statistics, vol. 8, 
419             pp. 118-120, 1937 
420      .. [3] Bullen, P.S., Handbook of Means and Their Inequalities, 2003 
421   
422      Examples 
423      -------- 
424      >>> from scipy.stats import pmean, hmean, gmean 
425      >>> pmean([1, 4], 1.3) 
426      2.639372938300652 
427      >>> pmean([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 1.3) 
428      4.157111214492084 
429      >>> pmean([1, 4, 7], -2, weights=[3, 1, 3]) 
430      1.4969684896631954 
431   
432      For p=-1, power mean is equal to harmonic mean: 
433   
434      >>> pmean([1, 4, 7], -1, weights=[3, 1, 3]) 
435      1.9029126213592233 
436      >>> hmean([1, 4, 7], weights=[3, 1, 3]) 
437      1.9029126213592233 
438   
439      For p=0, power mean is defined as the geometric mean: 
440   
441      >>> pmean([1, 4, 7], 0, weights=[3, 1, 3]) 
442      2.80668351922014 
443      >>> gmean([1, 4, 7], weights=[3, 1, 3]) 
444      2.80668351922014 
445   
446      """
447      if not isinstance(p, (int, float)):
448          raise ValueError("Power mean only defined for exponent of type int or "
449                           "float.")
450      if p == 0:
451          return gmean(a, axis=axis, dtype=dtype, weights=weights)
452  
453      xp = array_namespace(a, weights)
454      a = xp.asarray(a, dtype=dtype)
455  
456      if weights is not None:
457          weights = xp.asarray(weights, dtype=dtype)
458  
459      negative_mask = a < 0
460      if xp.any(negative_mask):
461          # `where` avoids having to be careful about dtypes and will work with
462          # JAX. This is the exceptional case, so it's OK to be a little slower.
463          # Won't work for array_api_strict for now, but see data-apis/array-api#807
464          a = xp.where(negative_mask, np.nan, a)
465          message = ("The power mean is only defined if all elements are "
466                     "non-negative; otherwise, the result is NaN.")
467          warnings.warn(message, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=2)
468  
469      with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
470          return _xp_mean(a**float(p), axis=axis, weights=weights)**(1/p)
471  
472  
473  ModeResult = namedtuple('ModeResult', ('mode', 'count'))
474  
475  
476  def _mode_result(mode, count):
477      # When a slice is empty, `_axis_nan_policy` automatically produces
478      # NaN for `mode` and `count`. This is a reasonable convention for `mode`,
479      # but `count` should not be NaN; it should be zero.
480      i = np.isnan(count)
481      if i.shape == ():
482          count = np.asarray(0, dtype=count.dtype)[()] if i else count
483      else:
484          count[i] = 0
485      return ModeResult(mode, count)
486  
487  
488  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(_mode_result, override={'vectorization': True,
489                                                    'nan_propagation': False})
490  def mode(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate', keepdims=False):
491      r"""Return an array of the modal (most common) value in the passed array. 
492   
493      If there is more than one such value, only one is returned. 
494      The bin-count for the modal bins is also returned. 
495   
496      Parameters 
497      ---------- 
498      a : array_like 
499          Numeric, n-dimensional array of which to find mode(s). 
500      axis : int or None, optional 
501          Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 
502          the whole array `a`. 
503      nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
504          Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
505          The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
506   
507            * 'propagate': treats nan as it would treat any other value 
508            * 'raise': throws an error 
509            * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
510      keepdims : bool, optional 
511          If set to ``False``, the `axis` over which the statistic is taken 
512          is consumed (eliminated from the output array). If set to ``True``, 
513          the `axis` is retained with size one, and the result will broadcast 
514          correctly against the input array. 
515   
516      Returns 
517      ------- 
518      mode : ndarray 
519          Array of modal values. 
520      count : ndarray 
521          Array of counts for each mode. 
522   
523      Notes 
524      ----- 
525      The mode  is calculated using `numpy.unique`. 
526      In NumPy versions 1.21 and after, all NaNs - even those with different 
527      binary representations - are treated as equivalent and counted as separate 
528      instances of the same value. 
529   
530      By convention, the mode of an empty array is NaN, and the associated count 
531      is zero. 
532   
533      Examples 
534      -------- 
535      >>> import numpy as np 
536      >>> a = np.array([[3, 0, 3, 7], 
537      ...               [3, 2, 6, 2], 
538      ...               [1, 7, 2, 8], 
539      ...               [3, 0, 6, 1], 
540      ...               [3, 2, 5, 5]]) 
541      >>> from scipy import stats 
542      >>> stats.mode(a, keepdims=True) 
543      ModeResult(mode=array([[3, 0, 6, 1]]), count=array([[4, 2, 2, 1]])) 
544   
545      To get mode of whole array, specify ``axis=None``: 
546   
547      >>> stats.mode(a, axis=None, keepdims=True) 
548      ModeResult(mode=[[3]], count=[[5]]) 
549      >>> stats.mode(a, axis=None, keepdims=False) 
550      ModeResult(mode=3, count=5) 
551   
552      """
553      # `axis`, `nan_policy`, and `keepdims` are handled by `_axis_nan_policy`
554      if not np.issubdtype(a.dtype, np.number):
555          message = ("Argument `a` is not recognized as numeric. "
556                     "Support for input that cannot be coerced to a numeric "
557                     "array was deprecated in SciPy 1.9.0 and removed in SciPy "
558                     "1.11.0. Please consider `np.unique`.")
559          raise TypeError(message)
560  
561      if a.size == 0:
562          NaN = _get_nan(a)
563          return ModeResult(*np.array([NaN, 0], dtype=NaN.dtype))
564  
565      vals, cnts = np.unique(a, return_counts=True)
566      modes, counts = vals[cnts.argmax()], cnts.max()
567      return ModeResult(modes[()], counts[()])
568  
569  
570  def _put_val_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive, val=np.nan, xp=None):
571      """Replace elements outside limits with a value. 
572   
573      This is primarily a utility function. 
574   
575      Parameters 
576      ---------- 
577      a : array 
578      limits : (float or None, float or None) 
579          A tuple consisting of the (lower limit, upper limit).  Elements in the 
580          input array less than the lower limit or greater than the upper limit 
581          will be replaced with `val`. None implies no limit. 
582      inclusive : (bool, bool) 
583          A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag).  These flags 
584          determine whether values exactly equal to lower or upper are allowed. 
585      val : float, default: NaN 
586          The value with which extreme elements of the array are replaced. 
587   
588      """
589      xp = array_namespace(a) if xp is None else xp
590      mask = xp.zeros(a.shape, dtype=xp.bool)
591      if limits is None:
592          return a, mask
593      lower_limit, upper_limit = limits
594      lower_include, upper_include = inclusive
595      if lower_limit is not None:
596          mask |= (a < lower_limit) if lower_include else a <= lower_limit
597      if upper_limit is not None:
598          mask |= (a > upper_limit) if upper_include else a >= upper_limit
599      if xp.all(mask):
600          raise ValueError("No array values within given limits")
601      if xp.any(mask):
602          # hopefully this (and many other instances of this idiom) are temporary when
603          # data-apis/array-api#807 is resolved
604          dtype = xp.asarray(1.).dtype if xp.isdtype(a.dtype, 'integral') else a.dtype
605          a = xp.where(mask, xp.asarray(val, dtype=dtype), a)
606      return a, mask
607  
608  
609  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
610      lambda x: x, n_outputs=1, default_axis=None,
611      result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,)
612  )
613  def tmean(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=None):
614      """Compute the trimmed mean. 
615   
616      This function finds the arithmetic mean of given values, ignoring values 
617      outside the given `limits`. 
618   
619      Parameters 
620      ---------- 
621      a : array_like 
622          Array of values. 
623      limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 
624          Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 
625          upper limit will be ignored.  When limits is None (default), then all 
626          values are used.  Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be 
627          None representing a half-open interval. 
628      inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 
629          A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag).  These flags 
630          determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 
631          are included.  The default value is (True, True). 
632      axis : int or None, optional 
633          Axis along which to compute test. Default is None. 
634   
635      Returns 
636      ------- 
637      tmean : ndarray 
638          Trimmed mean. 
639   
640      See Also 
641      -------- 
642      trim_mean : Returns mean after trimming a proportion from both tails. 
643   
644      Examples 
645      -------- 
646      >>> import numpy as np 
647      >>> from scipy import stats 
648      >>> x = np.arange(20) 
649      >>> stats.tmean(x) 
650      9.5 
651      >>> stats.tmean(x, (3,17)) 
652      10.0 
653   
654      """
655      xp = array_namespace(a)
656      a, mask = _put_val_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive, val=0., xp=xp)
657      # explicit dtype specification required due to data-apis/array-api-compat#152
658      sum = xp.sum(a, axis=axis, dtype=a.dtype)
659      n = xp.sum(xp.asarray(~mask, dtype=a.dtype), axis=axis, dtype=a.dtype)
660      mean = _lazywhere(n != 0, (sum, n), xp.divide, xp.nan)
661      return mean[()] if mean.ndim == 0 else mean
662  
663  
664  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
665      lambda x: x, n_outputs=1, result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,)
666  )
667  def tvar(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=0, ddof=1):
668      """Compute the trimmed variance. 
669   
670      This function computes the sample variance of an array of values, 
671      while ignoring values which are outside of given `limits`. 
672   
673      Parameters 
674      ---------- 
675      a : array_like 
676          Array of values. 
677      limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 
678          Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 
679          upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are 
680          used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None 
681          representing a half-open interval.  The default value is None. 
682      inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 
683          A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag).  These flags 
684          determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 
685          are included.  The default value is (True, True). 
686      axis : int or None, optional 
687          Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 
688          whole array `a`. 
689      ddof : int, optional 
690          Delta degrees of freedom.  Default is 1. 
691   
692      Returns 
693      ------- 
694      tvar : float 
695          Trimmed variance. 
696   
697      Notes 
698      ----- 
699      `tvar` computes the unbiased sample variance, i.e. it uses a correction 
700      factor ``n / (n - 1)``. 
701   
702      Examples 
703      -------- 
704      >>> import numpy as np 
705      >>> from scipy import stats 
706      >>> x = np.arange(20) 
707      >>> stats.tvar(x) 
708      35.0 
709      >>> stats.tvar(x, (3,17)) 
710      20.0 
711   
712      """
713      xp = array_namespace(a)
714      a, _ = _put_val_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive, xp=xp)
715      with warnings.catch_warnings():
716          warnings.simplefilter("ignore", SmallSampleWarning)
717          # Currently, this behaves like nan_policy='omit' for alternative array
718          # backends, but nan_policy='propagate' will be handled for other backends
719          # by the axis_nan_policy decorator shortly.
720          return _xp_var(a, correction=ddof, axis=axis, nan_policy='omit', xp=xp)
721  
722  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
723      lambda x: x, n_outputs=1, result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,)
724  )
725  def tmin(a, lowerlimit=None, axis=0, inclusive=True, nan_policy='propagate'):
726      """Compute the trimmed minimum. 
727   
728      This function finds the minimum value of an array `a` along the 
729      specified axis, but only considering values greater than a specified 
730      lower limit. 
731   
732      Parameters 
733      ---------- 
734      a : array_like 
735          Array of values. 
736      lowerlimit : None or float, optional 
737          Values in the input array less than the given limit will be ignored. 
738          When lowerlimit is None, then all values are used. The default value 
739          is None. 
740      axis : int or None, optional 
741          Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 
742          whole array `a`. 
743      inclusive : {True, False}, optional 
744          This flag determines whether values exactly equal to the lower limit 
745          are included.  The default value is True. 
746   
747      Returns 
748      ------- 
749      tmin : float, int or ndarray 
750          Trimmed minimum. 
751   
752      Examples 
753      -------- 
754      >>> import numpy as np 
755      >>> from scipy import stats 
756      >>> x = np.arange(20) 
757      >>> stats.tmin(x) 
758      0 
759   
760      >>> stats.tmin(x, 13) 
761      13 
762   
763      >>> stats.tmin(x, 13, inclusive=False) 
764      14 
765   
766      """
767      xp = array_namespace(a)
768  
769      # remember original dtype; _put_val_to_limits might need to change it
770      dtype = a.dtype
771      a, mask = _put_val_to_limits(a, (lowerlimit, None), (inclusive, None),
772                                   val=xp.inf, xp=xp)
773  
774      min = xp.min(a, axis=axis)
775      n = xp.sum(xp.asarray(~mask, dtype=a.dtype), axis=axis)
776      res = xp.where(n != 0, min, xp.nan)
777  
778      if not xp.any(xp.isnan(res)):
779          # needed if input is of integer dtype
780          res = xp.astype(res, dtype, copy=False)
781  
782      return res[()] if res.ndim == 0 else res
783  
784  
785  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
786      lambda x: x, n_outputs=1, result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,)
787  )
788  def tmax(a, upperlimit=None, axis=0, inclusive=True, nan_policy='propagate'):
789      """Compute the trimmed maximum. 
790   
791      This function computes the maximum value of an array along a given axis, 
792      while ignoring values larger than a specified upper limit. 
793   
794      Parameters 
795      ---------- 
796      a : array_like 
797          Array of values. 
798      upperlimit : None or float, optional 
799          Values in the input array greater than the given limit will be ignored. 
800          When upperlimit is None, then all values are used. The default value 
801          is None. 
802      axis : int or None, optional 
803          Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 
804          whole array `a`. 
805      inclusive : {True, False}, optional 
806          This flag determines whether values exactly equal to the upper limit 
807          are included.  The default value is True. 
808   
809      Returns 
810      ------- 
811      tmax : float, int or ndarray 
812          Trimmed maximum. 
813   
814      Examples 
815      -------- 
816      >>> import numpy as np 
817      >>> from scipy import stats 
818      >>> x = np.arange(20) 
819      >>> stats.tmax(x) 
820      19 
821   
822      >>> stats.tmax(x, 13) 
823      13 
824   
825      >>> stats.tmax(x, 13, inclusive=False) 
826      12 
827   
828      """
829      xp = array_namespace(a)
830  
831      # remember original dtype; _put_val_to_limits might need to change it
832      dtype = a.dtype
833      a, mask = _put_val_to_limits(a, (None, upperlimit), (None, inclusive),
834                                   val=-xp.inf, xp=xp)
835  
836      max = xp.max(a, axis=axis)
837      n = xp.sum(xp.asarray(~mask, dtype=a.dtype), axis=axis)
838      res = xp.where(n != 0, max, xp.nan)
839  
840      if not xp.any(xp.isnan(res)):
841          # needed if input is of integer dtype
842          res = xp.astype(res, dtype, copy=False)
843  
844      return res[()] if res.ndim == 0 else res
845  
846  
847  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
848      lambda x: x, n_outputs=1, result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,)
849  )
850  def tstd(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=0, ddof=1):
851      """Compute the trimmed sample standard deviation. 
852   
853      This function finds the sample standard deviation of given values, 
854      ignoring values outside the given `limits`. 
855   
856      Parameters 
857      ---------- 
858      a : array_like 
859          Array of values. 
860      limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 
861          Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 
862          upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are 
863          used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None 
864          representing a half-open interval.  The default value is None. 
865      inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 
866          A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag).  These flags 
867          determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 
868          are included.  The default value is (True, True). 
869      axis : int or None, optional 
870          Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 
871          whole array `a`. 
872      ddof : int, optional 
873          Delta degrees of freedom.  Default is 1. 
874   
875      Returns 
876      ------- 
877      tstd : float 
878          Trimmed sample standard deviation. 
879   
880      Notes 
881      ----- 
882      `tstd` computes the unbiased sample standard deviation, i.e. it uses a 
883      correction factor ``n / (n - 1)``. 
884   
885      Examples 
886      -------- 
887      >>> import numpy as np 
888      >>> from scipy import stats 
889      >>> x = np.arange(20) 
890      >>> stats.tstd(x) 
891      5.9160797830996161 
892      >>> stats.tstd(x, (3,17)) 
893      4.4721359549995796 
894   
895      """
896      return tvar(a, limits, inclusive, axis, ddof, _no_deco=True)**0.5
897  
898  
899  @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
900      lambda x: x, n_outputs=1, result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,)
901  )
902  def tsem(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=0, ddof=1):
903      """Compute the trimmed standard error of the mean. 
904   
905      This function finds the standard error of the mean for given 
906      values, ignoring values outside the given `limits`. 
907   
908      Parameters 
909      ---------- 
910      a : array_like 
911          Array of values. 
912      limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional 
913          Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the 
914          upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are 
915          used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None 
916          representing a half-open interval.  The default value is None. 
917      inclusive : (bool, bool), optional 
918          A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag).  These flags 
919          determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits 
920          are included.  The default value is (True, True). 
921      axis : int or None, optional 
922          Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the 
923          whole array `a`. 
924      ddof : int, optional 
925          Delta degrees of freedom.  Default is 1. 
926   
927      Returns 
928      ------- 
929      tsem : float 
930          Trimmed standard error of the mean. 
931   
932      Notes 
933      ----- 
934      `tsem` uses unbiased sample standard deviation, i.e. it uses a 
935      correction factor ``n / (n - 1)``. 
936   
937      Examples 
938      -------- 
939      >>> import numpy as np 
940      >>> from scipy import stats 
941      >>> x = np.arange(20) 
942      >>> stats.tsem(x) 
943      1.3228756555322954 
944      >>> stats.tsem(x, (3,17)) 
945      1.1547005383792515 
946   
947      """
948      xp = array_namespace(a)
949      a, _ = _put_val_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive, xp=xp)
950  
951      with warnings.catch_warnings():
952          warnings.simplefilter("ignore", SmallSampleWarning)
953          # Currently, this behaves like nan_policy='omit' for alternative array
954          # backends, but nan_policy='propagate' will be handled for other backends
955          # by the axis_nan_policy decorator shortly.
956          sd = _xp_var(a, correction=ddof, axis=axis, nan_policy='omit', xp=xp)**0.5
957  
958      n_obs = xp.sum(~xp.isnan(a), axis=axis, dtype=sd.dtype)
959      return sd / n_obs**0.5
960  
961  
962  #####################################
963  #              MOMENTS              #
964  #####################################
965  
966  
967  def _moment_outputs(kwds, default_order=1):
968      order = np.atleast_1d(kwds.get('order', default_order))
969      message = "`order` must be a scalar or a non-empty 1D array."
970      if order.size == 0 or order.ndim > 1:
971          raise ValueError(message)
972      return len(order)
973  
974  
975  def _moment_result_object(*args):
976      if len(args) == 1:
977          return args[0]
978      return np.asarray(args)
979  
980  
981  # When `order` is array-like with size > 1, moment produces an *array*
982  # rather than a tuple, but the zeroth dimension is to be treated like
983  # separate outputs. It is important to make the distinction between
984  # separate outputs when adding the reduced axes back (`keepdims=True`).
985  def _moment_tuple(x, n_out):
986      return tuple(x) if n_out > 1 else (x,)
987  
988  
989  # `moment` fits into the `_axis_nan_policy` pattern, but it is a bit unusual
990  # because the number of outputs is variable. Specifically,
991  # `result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,)` may be surprising for a function that
992  # can produce more than one output, but it is intended here.
993  # When `moment is called to produce the output:
994  # - `result_to_tuple` packs the returned array into a single-element tuple,
995  # - `_moment_result_object` extracts and returns that single element.
996  # However, when the input array is empty, `moment` is never called. Instead,
997  # - `_check_empty_inputs` is used to produce an empty array with the
998  #   appropriate dimensions.
999  # - A list comprehension creates the appropriate number of copies of this
1000 #   array, depending on `n_outputs`.
1001 # - This list - which may have multiple elements - is passed into
1002 #   `_moment_result_object`.
1003 # - If there is a single output, `_moment_result_object` extracts and returns
1004 #   the single output from the list.
1005 # - If there are multiple outputs, and therefore multiple elements in the list,
1006 #   `_moment_result_object` converts the list of arrays to a single array and
1007 #   returns it.
1008 # Currently, this leads to a slight inconsistency: when the input array is
1009 # empty, there is no distinction between the `moment` function being called
1010 # with parameter `order=1` and `order=[1]`; the latter *should* produce
1011 # the same as the former but with a singleton zeroth dimension.
1012 @_rename_parameter('moment', 'order')
1013 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(  # noqa: E302
1014     _moment_result_object, n_samples=1, result_to_tuple=_moment_tuple,
1015     n_outputs=_moment_outputs
1016 )
1017 def moment(a, order=1, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate', *, center=None):
1018     r"""Calculate the nth moment about the mean for a sample. 
1019  
1020     A moment is a specific quantitative measure of the shape of a set of 
1021     points. It is often used to calculate coefficients of skewness and kurtosis 
1022     due to its close relationship with them. 
1023  
1024     Parameters 
1025     ---------- 
1026     a : array_like 
1027        Input array. 
1028     order : int or 1-D array_like of ints, optional 
1029        Order of central moment that is returned. Default is 1. 
1030     axis : int or None, optional 
1031        Axis along which the central moment is computed. Default is 0. 
1032        If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
1033     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
1034         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
1035         The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
1036  
1037           * 'propagate': returns nan 
1038           * 'raise': throws an error 
1039           * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
1040  
1041     center : float or None, optional 
1042        The point about which moments are taken. This can be the sample mean, 
1043        the origin, or any other be point. If `None` (default) compute the 
1044        center as the sample mean. 
1045  
1046     Returns 
1047     ------- 
1048     n-th moment about the `center` : ndarray or float 
1049        The appropriate moment along the given axis or over all values if axis 
1050        is None. The denominator for the moment calculation is the number of 
1051        observations, no degrees of freedom correction is done. 
1052  
1053     See Also 
1054     -------- 
1055     kurtosis, skew, describe 
1056  
1057     Notes 
1058     ----- 
1059     The k-th moment of a data sample is: 
1060  
1061     .. math:: 
1062  
1063         m_k = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^n (x_i - c)^k 
1064  
1065     Where `n` is the number of samples, and `c` is the center around which the 
1066     moment is calculated. This function uses exponentiation by squares [1]_ for 
1067     efficiency. 
1068  
1069     Note that, if `a` is an empty array (``a.size == 0``), array `moment` with 
1070     one element (`moment.size == 1`) is treated the same as scalar `moment` 
1071     (``np.isscalar(moment)``). This might produce arrays of unexpected shape. 
1072  
1073     References 
1074     ---------- 
1075     .. [1] https://eli.thegreenplace.net/2009/03/21/efficient-integer-exponentiation-algorithms 
1076  
1077     Examples 
1078     -------- 
1079     >>> from scipy.stats import moment 
1080     >>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], order=1) 
1081     0.0 
1082     >>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], order=2) 
1083     2.0 
1084  
1085     """
1086     xp = array_namespace(a)
1087     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis, xp=xp)
1088 
1089     if xp.isdtype(a.dtype, 'integral'):
1090         a = xp.asarray(a, dtype=xp.float64)
1091     else:
1092         a = xp.asarray(a)
1093 
1094     order = xp.asarray(order, dtype=a.dtype)
1095     if xp_size(order) == 0:
1096         # This is tested by `_moment_outputs`, which is run by the `_axis_nan_policy`
1097         # decorator. Currently, the `_axis_nan_policy` decorator is skipped when `a`
1098         # is a non-NumPy array, so we need to check again. When the decorator is
1099         # updated for array API compatibility, we can remove this second check.
1100         raise ValueError("`order` must be a scalar or a non-empty 1D array.")
1101     if xp.any(order != xp.round(order)):
1102         raise ValueError("All elements of `order` must be integral.")
1103     order = order[()] if order.ndim == 0 else order
1104 
1105     # for array_like order input, return a value for each.
1106     if order.ndim > 0:
1107         # Calculated the mean once at most, and only if it will be used
1108         calculate_mean = center is None and xp.any(order > 1)
1109         mean = xp.mean(a, axis=axis, keepdims=True) if calculate_mean else None
1110         mmnt = []
1111         for i in range(order.shape[0]):
1112             order_i = order[i]
1113             if center is None and order_i > 1:
1114                 mmnt.append(_moment(a, order_i, axis, mean=mean)[np.newaxis, ...])
1115             else:
1116                 mmnt.append(_moment(a, order_i, axis, mean=center)[np.newaxis, ...])
1117         return xp.concat(mmnt, axis=0)
1118     else:
1119         return _moment(a, order, axis, mean=center)
1120 
1121 
1122 def _demean(a, mean, axis, *, xp, precision_warning=True):
1123     # subtracts `mean` from `a` and returns the result,
1124     # warning if there is catastrophic cancellation. `mean`
1125     # must be the mean of `a` along axis with `keepdims=True`.
1126     # Used in e.g. `_moment`, `_zscore`, `_xp_var`. See gh-15905.
1127     a_zero_mean = a - mean
1128 
1129     if xp_size(a_zero_mean) == 0:
1130         return a_zero_mean
1131 
1132     eps = xp.finfo(mean.dtype).eps * 10
1133 
1134     with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
1135         rel_diff = xp.max(xp.abs(a_zero_mean), axis=axis,
1136                           keepdims=True) / xp.abs(mean)
1137     with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
1138         precision_loss = xp.any(rel_diff < eps)
1139     n = (xp_size(a) if axis is None
1140          # compact way to deal with axis tuples or ints
1141          else np.prod(np.asarray(a.shape)[np.asarray(axis)]))
1142 
1143     if precision_loss and n > 1 and precision_warning:
1144         message = ("Precision loss occurred in moment calculation due to "
1145                    "catastrophic cancellation. This occurs when the data "
1146                    "are nearly identical. Results may be unreliable.")
1147         warnings.warn(message, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=5)
1148     return a_zero_mean
1149 
1150 
1151 def _moment(a, order, axis, *, mean=None, xp=None):
1152     """Vectorized calculation of raw moment about specified center 
1153  
1154     When `mean` is None, the mean is computed and used as the center; 
1155     otherwise, the provided value is used as the center. 
1156  
1157     """
1158     xp = array_namespace(a) if xp is None else xp
1159 
1160     if xp.isdtype(a.dtype, 'integral'):
1161         a = xp.asarray(a, dtype=xp.float64)
1162 
1163     dtype = a.dtype
1164 
1165     # moment of empty array is the same regardless of order
1166     if xp_size(a) == 0:
1167         return xp.mean(a, axis=axis)
1168 
1169     if order == 0 or (order == 1 and mean is None):
1170         # By definition the zeroth moment is always 1, and the first *central*
1171         # moment is 0.
1172         shape = list(a.shape)
1173         del shape[axis]
1174 
1175         temp = (xp.ones(shape, dtype=dtype) if order == 0
1176                 else xp.zeros(shape, dtype=dtype))
1177         return temp[()] if temp.ndim == 0 else temp
1178 
1179     # Exponentiation by squares: form exponent sequence
1180     n_list = [order]
1181     current_n = order
1182     while current_n > 2:
1183         if current_n % 2:
1184             current_n = (current_n - 1) / 2
1185         else:
1186             current_n /= 2
1187         n_list.append(current_n)
1188 
1189     # Starting point for exponentiation by squares
1190     mean = (xp.mean(a, axis=axis, keepdims=True) if mean is None
1191             else xp.asarray(mean, dtype=dtype))
1192     mean = mean[()] if mean.ndim == 0 else mean
1193     a_zero_mean = _demean(a, mean, axis, xp=xp)
1194 
1195     if n_list[-1] == 1:
1196         s = xp.asarray(a_zero_mean, copy=True)
1197     else:
1198         s = a_zero_mean**2
1199 
1200     # Perform multiplications
1201     for n in n_list[-2::-1]:
1202         s = s**2
1203         if n % 2:
1204             s *= a_zero_mean
1205     return xp.mean(s, axis=axis)
1206 
1207 
1208 def _var(x, axis=0, ddof=0, mean=None, xp=None):
1209     # Calculate variance of sample, warning if precision is lost
1210     xp = array_namespace(x) if xp is None else xp
1211     var = _moment(x, 2, axis, mean=mean, xp=xp)
1212     if ddof != 0:
1213         n = x.shape[axis] if axis is not None else xp_size(x)
1214         var *= np.divide(n, n-ddof)  # to avoid error on division by zero
1215     return var
1216 
1217 
1218 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
1219     lambda x: x, result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,), n_outputs=1
1220 )
1221 # nan_policy handled by `_axis_nan_policy`, but needs to be left
1222 # in signature to preserve use as a positional argument
1223 def skew(a, axis=0, bias=True, nan_policy='propagate'):
1224     r"""Compute the sample skewness of a data set. 
1225  
1226     For normally distributed data, the skewness should be about zero. For 
1227     unimodal continuous distributions, a skewness value greater than zero means 
1228     that there is more weight in the right tail of the distribution. The 
1229     function `skewtest` can be used to determine if the skewness value 
1230     is close enough to zero, statistically speaking. 
1231  
1232     Parameters 
1233     ---------- 
1234     a : ndarray 
1235         Input array. 
1236     axis : int or None, optional 
1237         Axis along which skewness is calculated. Default is 0. 
1238         If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
1239     bias : bool, optional 
1240         If False, then the calculations are corrected for statistical bias. 
1241     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
1242         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
1243         The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
1244  
1245           * 'propagate': returns nan 
1246           * 'raise': throws an error 
1247           * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
1248  
1249     Returns 
1250     ------- 
1251     skewness : ndarray 
1252         The skewness of values along an axis, returning NaN where all values 
1253         are equal. 
1254  
1255     Notes 
1256     ----- 
1257     The sample skewness is computed as the Fisher-Pearson coefficient 
1258     of skewness, i.e. 
1259  
1260     .. math:: 
1261  
1262         g_1=\frac{m_3}{m_2^{3/2}} 
1263  
1264     where 
1265  
1266     .. math:: 
1267  
1268         m_i=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N(x[n]-\bar{x})^i 
1269  
1270     is the biased sample :math:`i\texttt{th}` central moment, and 
1271     :math:`\bar{x}` is 
1272     the sample mean.  If ``bias`` is False, the calculations are 
1273     corrected for bias and the value computed is the adjusted 
1274     Fisher-Pearson standardized moment coefficient, i.e. 
1275  
1276     .. math:: 
1277  
1278         G_1=\frac{k_3}{k_2^{3/2}}= 
1279             \frac{\sqrt{N(N-1)}}{N-2}\frac{m_3}{m_2^{3/2}}. 
1280  
1281     References 
1282     ---------- 
1283     .. [1] Zwillinger, D. and Kokoska, S. (2000). CRC Standard 
1284        Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New 
1285        York. 2000. 
1286        Section 2.2.24.1 
1287  
1288     Examples 
1289     -------- 
1290     >>> from scipy.stats import skew 
1291     >>> skew([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) 
1292     0.0 
1293     >>> skew([2, 8, 0, 4, 1, 9, 9, 0]) 
1294     0.2650554122698573 
1295  
1296     """
1297     xp = array_namespace(a)
1298     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis, xp=xp)
1299     n = a.shape[axis]
1300 
1301     mean = xp.mean(a, axis=axis, keepdims=True)
1302     mean_reduced = xp.squeeze(mean, axis=axis)  # needed later
1303     m2 = _moment(a, 2, axis, mean=mean, xp=xp)
1304     m3 = _moment(a, 3, axis, mean=mean, xp=xp)
1305     with np.errstate(all='ignore'):
1306         eps = xp.finfo(m2.dtype).eps
1307         zero = m2 <= (eps * mean_reduced)**2
1308         vals = xp.where(zero, xp.asarray(xp.nan), m3 / m2**1.5)
1309     if not bias:
1310         can_correct = ~zero & (n > 2)
1311         if xp.any(can_correct):
1312             m2 = m2[can_correct]
1313             m3 = m3[can_correct]
1314             nval = ((n - 1.0) * n)**0.5 / (n - 2.0) * m3 / m2**1.5
1315             vals[can_correct] = nval
1316 
1317     return vals[()] if vals.ndim == 0 else vals
1318 
1319 
1320 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(
1321     lambda x: x, result_to_tuple=lambda x: (x,), n_outputs=1
1322 )
1323 # nan_policy handled by `_axis_nan_policy`, but needs to be left
1324 # in signature to preserve use as a positional argument
1325 def kurtosis(a, axis=0, fisher=True, bias=True, nan_policy='propagate'):
1326     """Compute the kurtosis (Fisher or Pearson) of a dataset. 
1327  
1328     Kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by the square of the 
1329     variance. If Fisher's definition is used, then 3.0 is subtracted from 
1330     the result to give 0.0 for a normal distribution. 
1331  
1332     If bias is False then the kurtosis is calculated using k statistics to 
1333     eliminate bias coming from biased moment estimators 
1334  
1335     Use `kurtosistest` to see if result is close enough to normal. 
1336  
1337     Parameters 
1338     ---------- 
1339     a : array 
1340         Data for which the kurtosis is calculated. 
1341     axis : int or None, optional 
1342         Axis along which the kurtosis is calculated. Default is 0. 
1343         If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
1344     fisher : bool, optional 
1345         If True, Fisher's definition is used (normal ==> 0.0). If False, 
1346         Pearson's definition is used (normal ==> 3.0). 
1347     bias : bool, optional 
1348         If False, then the calculations are corrected for statistical bias. 
1349     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
1350         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 'propagate' returns nan, 
1351         'raise' throws an error, 'omit' performs the calculations ignoring nan 
1352         values. Default is 'propagate'. 
1353  
1354     Returns 
1355     ------- 
1356     kurtosis : array 
1357         The kurtosis of values along an axis, returning NaN where all values 
1358         are equal. 
1359  
1360     References 
1361     ---------- 
1362     .. [1] Zwillinger, D. and Kokoska, S. (2000). CRC Standard 
1363        Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New 
1364        York. 2000. 
1365  
1366     Examples 
1367     -------- 
1368     In Fisher's definition, the kurtosis of the normal distribution is zero. 
1369     In the following example, the kurtosis is close to zero, because it was 
1370     calculated from the dataset, not from the continuous distribution. 
1371  
1372     >>> import numpy as np 
1373     >>> from scipy.stats import norm, kurtosis 
1374     >>> data = norm.rvs(size=1000, random_state=3) 
1375     >>> kurtosis(data) 
1376     -0.06928694200380558 
1377  
1378     The distribution with a higher kurtosis has a heavier tail. 
1379     The zero valued kurtosis of the normal distribution in Fisher's definition 
1380     can serve as a reference point. 
1381  
1382     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
1383     >>> import scipy.stats as stats 
1384     >>> from scipy.stats import kurtosis 
1385  
1386     >>> x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 100) 
1387     >>> ax = plt.subplot() 
1388     >>> distnames = ['laplace', 'norm', 'uniform'] 
1389  
1390     >>> for distname in distnames: 
1391     ...     if distname == 'uniform': 
1392     ...         dist = getattr(stats, distname)(loc=-2, scale=4) 
1393     ...     else: 
1394     ...         dist = getattr(stats, distname) 
1395     ...     data = dist.rvs(size=1000) 
1396     ...     kur = kurtosis(data, fisher=True) 
1397     ...     y = dist.pdf(x) 
1398     ...     ax.plot(x, y, label="{}, {}".format(distname, round(kur, 3))) 
1399     ...     ax.legend() 
1400  
1401     The Laplace distribution has a heavier tail than the normal distribution. 
1402     The uniform distribution (which has negative kurtosis) has the thinnest 
1403     tail. 
1404  
1405     """
1406     xp = array_namespace(a)
1407     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis, xp=xp)
1408 
1409     n = a.shape[axis]
1410     mean = xp.mean(a, axis=axis, keepdims=True)
1411     mean_reduced = xp.squeeze(mean, axis=axis)  # needed later
1412     m2 = _moment(a, 2, axis, mean=mean, xp=xp)
1413     m4 = _moment(a, 4, axis, mean=mean, xp=xp)
1414     with np.errstate(all='ignore'):
1415         zero = m2 <= (xp.finfo(m2.dtype).eps * mean_reduced)**2
1416         NaN = _get_nan(m4, xp=xp)
1417         vals = xp.where(zero, NaN, m4 / m2**2.0)
1418 
1419     if not bias:
1420         can_correct = ~zero & (n > 3)
1421         if xp.any(can_correct):
1422             m2 = m2[can_correct]
1423             m4 = m4[can_correct]
1424             nval = 1.0/(n-2)/(n-3) * ((n**2-1.0)*m4/m2**2.0 - 3*(n-1)**2.0)
1425             vals[can_correct] = nval + 3.0
1426 
1427     vals = vals - 3 if fisher else vals
1428     return vals[()] if vals.ndim == 0 else vals
1429 
1430 
1431 DescribeResult = namedtuple('DescribeResult',
1432                             ('nobs', 'minmax', 'mean', 'variance', 'skewness',
1433                              'kurtosis'))
1434 
1435 
1436 def describe(a, axis=0, ddof=1, bias=True, nan_policy='propagate'):
1437     """Compute several descriptive statistics of the passed array. 
1438  
1439     Parameters 
1440     ---------- 
1441     a : array_like 
1442         Input data. 
1443     axis : int or None, optional 
1444         Axis along which statistics are calculated. Default is 0. 
1445         If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
1446     ddof : int, optional 
1447         Delta degrees of freedom (only for variance).  Default is 1. 
1448     bias : bool, optional 
1449         If False, then the skewness and kurtosis calculations are corrected 
1450         for statistical bias. 
1451     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
1452         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
1453         The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
1454  
1455         * 'propagate': returns nan 
1456         * 'raise': throws an error 
1457         * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
1458  
1459     Returns 
1460     ------- 
1461     nobs : int or ndarray of ints 
1462         Number of observations (length of data along `axis`). 
1463         When 'omit' is chosen as nan_policy, the length along each axis 
1464         slice is counted separately. 
1465     minmax: tuple of ndarrays or floats 
1466         Minimum and maximum value of `a` along the given axis. 
1467     mean : ndarray or float 
1468         Arithmetic mean of `a` along the given axis. 
1469     variance : ndarray or float 
1470         Unbiased variance of `a` along the given axis; denominator is number 
1471         of observations minus one. 
1472     skewness : ndarray or float 
1473         Skewness of `a` along the given axis, based on moment calculations 
1474         with denominator equal to the number of observations, i.e. no degrees 
1475         of freedom correction. 
1476     kurtosis : ndarray or float 
1477         Kurtosis (Fisher) of `a` along the given axis.  The kurtosis is 
1478         normalized so that it is zero for the normal distribution.  No 
1479         degrees of freedom are used. 
1480  
1481     Raises 
1482     ------ 
1483     ValueError 
1484         If size of `a` is 0. 
1485  
1486     See Also 
1487     -------- 
1488     skew, kurtosis 
1489  
1490     Examples 
1491     -------- 
1492     >>> import numpy as np 
1493     >>> from scipy import stats 
1494     >>> a = np.arange(10) 
1495     >>> stats.describe(a) 
1496     DescribeResult(nobs=10, minmax=(0, 9), mean=4.5, 
1497                    variance=9.166666666666666, skewness=0.0, 
1498                    kurtosis=-1.2242424242424244) 
1499     >>> b = [[1, 2], [3, 4]] 
1500     >>> stats.describe(b) 
1501     DescribeResult(nobs=2, minmax=(array([1, 2]), array([3, 4])), 
1502                    mean=array([2., 3.]), variance=array([2., 2.]), 
1503                    skewness=array([0., 0.]), kurtosis=array([-2., -2.])) 
1504  
1505     """
1506     xp = array_namespace(a)
1507     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis, xp=xp)
1508 
1509     contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
1510 
1511     if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
1512         # only NumPy gets here; `_contains_nan` raises error for the rest
1513         a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
1514         return mstats_basic.describe(a, axis, ddof, bias)
1515 
1516     if xp_size(a) == 0:
1517         raise ValueError("The input must not be empty.")
1518 
1519     n = a.shape[axis]
1520     mm = (xp.min(a, axis=axis), xp.max(a, axis=axis))
1521     m = xp.mean(a, axis=axis)
1522     v = _var(a, axis=axis, ddof=ddof, xp=xp)
1523     sk = skew(a, axis, bias=bias)
1524     kurt = kurtosis(a, axis, bias=bias)
1525 
1526     return DescribeResult(n, mm, m, v, sk, kurt)
1527 
1528 #####################################
1529 #         NORMALITY TESTS           #
1530 #####################################
1531 
1532 
1533 def _get_pvalue(statistic, distribution, alternative, symmetric=True, xp=None):
1534     """Get p-value given the statistic, (continuous) distribution, and alternative"""
1535     xp = array_namespace(statistic) if xp is None else xp
1536 
1537     if alternative == 'less':
1538         pvalue = distribution.cdf(statistic)
1539     elif alternative == 'greater':
1540         pvalue = distribution.sf(statistic)
1541     elif alternative == 'two-sided':
1542         pvalue = 2 * (distribution.sf(xp.abs(statistic)) if symmetric
1543                       else xp.minimum(distribution.cdf(statistic),
1544                                       distribution.sf(statistic)))
1545     else:
1546         message = "`alternative` must be 'less', 'greater', or 'two-sided'."
1547         raise ValueError(message)
1548 
1549     return pvalue
1550 
1551 
1552 SkewtestResult = namedtuple('SkewtestResult', ('statistic', 'pvalue'))
1553 
1554 
1555 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(SkewtestResult, n_samples=1, too_small=7)
1556 # nan_policy handled by `_axis_nan_policy`, but needs to be left
1557 # in signature to preserve use as a positional argument
1558 def skewtest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate', alternative='two-sided'):
1559     r"""Test whether the skew is different from the normal distribution. 
1560  
1561     This function tests the null hypothesis that the skewness of 
1562     the population that the sample was drawn from is the same 
1563     as that of a corresponding normal distribution. 
1564  
1565     Parameters 
1566     ---------- 
1567     a : array 
1568         The data to be tested. Must contain at least eight observations. 
1569     axis : int or None, optional 
1570        Axis along which statistics are calculated. Default is 0. 
1571        If None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
1572     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
1573         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
1574         The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
1575  
1576         * 'propagate': returns nan 
1577         * 'raise': throws an error 
1578         * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
1579  
1580     alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional 
1581         Defines the alternative hypothesis. Default is 'two-sided'. 
1582         The following options are available: 
1583  
1584         * 'two-sided': the skewness of the distribution underlying the sample 
1585           is different from that of the normal distribution (i.e. 0) 
1586         * 'less': the skewness of the distribution underlying the sample 
1587           is less than that of the normal distribution 
1588         * 'greater': the skewness of the distribution underlying the sample 
1589           is greater than that of the normal distribution 
1590  
1591         .. versionadded:: 1.7.0 
1592  
1593     Returns 
1594     ------- 
1595     statistic : float 
1596         The computed z-score for this test. 
1597     pvalue : float 
1598         The p-value for the hypothesis test. 
1599  
1600     See Also 
1601     -------- 
1602     :ref:`hypothesis_skewtest` : Extended example 
1603  
1604     Notes 
1605     ----- 
1606     The sample size must be at least 8. 
1607  
1608     References 
1609     ---------- 
1610     .. [1] R. B. D'Agostino, A. J. Belanger and R. B. D'Agostino Jr., 
1611             "A suggestion for using powerful and informative tests of 
1612             normality", American Statistician 44, pp. 316-321, 1990. 
1613  
1614     Examples 
1615     -------- 
1616  
1617     >>> from scipy.stats import skewtest 
1618     >>> skewtest([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]) 
1619     SkewtestResult(statistic=1.0108048609177787, pvalue=0.3121098361421897) 
1620     >>> skewtest([2, 8, 0, 4, 1, 9, 9, 0]) 
1621     SkewtestResult(statistic=0.44626385374196975, pvalue=0.6554066631275459) 
1622     >>> skewtest([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8000]) 
1623     SkewtestResult(statistic=3.571773510360407, pvalue=0.0003545719905823133) 
1624     >>> skewtest([100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 101]) 
1625     SkewtestResult(statistic=3.5717766638478072, pvalue=0.000354567720281634) 
1626     >>> skewtest([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], alternative='less') 
1627     SkewtestResult(statistic=1.0108048609177787, pvalue=0.8439450819289052) 
1628     >>> skewtest([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], alternative='greater') 
1629     SkewtestResult(statistic=1.0108048609177787, pvalue=0.15605491807109484) 
1630  
1631     For a more detailed example, see :ref:`hypothesis_skewtest`. 
1632     """
1633     xp = array_namespace(a)
1634     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis, xp=xp)
1635 
1636     b2 = skew(a, axis, _no_deco=True)
1637     n = a.shape[axis]
1638     if n < 8:
1639         message = ("`skewtest` requires at least 8 observations; "
1640                    f"only {n=} observations were given.")
1641         raise ValueError(message)
1642 
1643     y = b2 * math.sqrt(((n + 1) * (n + 3)) / (6.0 * (n - 2)))
1644     beta2 = (3.0 * (n**2 + 27*n - 70) * (n+1) * (n+3) /
1645              ((n-2.0) * (n+5) * (n+7) * (n+9)))
1646     W2 = -1 + math.sqrt(2 * (beta2 - 1))
1647     delta = 1 / math.sqrt(0.5 * math.log(W2))
1648     alpha = math.sqrt(2.0 / (W2 - 1))
1649     y = xp.where(y == 0, xp.asarray(1, dtype=y.dtype), y)
1650     Z = delta * xp.log(y / alpha + xp.sqrt((y / alpha)**2 + 1))
1651 
1652     pvalue = _get_pvalue(Z, _SimpleNormal(), alternative, xp=xp)
1653 
1654     Z = Z[()] if Z.ndim == 0 else Z
1655     pvalue = pvalue[()] if pvalue.ndim == 0 else pvalue
1656     return SkewtestResult(Z, pvalue)
1657 
1658 
1659 KurtosistestResult = namedtuple('KurtosistestResult', ('statistic', 'pvalue'))
1660 
1661 
1662 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(KurtosistestResult, n_samples=1, too_small=4)
1663 def kurtosistest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate', alternative='two-sided'):
1664     r"""Test whether a dataset has normal kurtosis. 
1665  
1666     This function tests the null hypothesis that the kurtosis 
1667     of the population from which the sample was drawn is that 
1668     of the normal distribution. 
1669  
1670     Parameters 
1671     ---------- 
1672     a : array 
1673         Array of the sample data. Must contain at least five observations. 
1674     axis : int or None, optional 
1675        Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None, 
1676        compute over the whole array `a`. 
1677     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
1678         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
1679         The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
1680  
1681         * 'propagate': returns nan 
1682         * 'raise': throws an error 
1683         * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
1684     alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional 
1685         Defines the alternative hypothesis. 
1686         The following options are available (default is 'two-sided'): 
1687  
1688         * 'two-sided': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample 
1689           is different from that of the normal distribution 
1690         * 'less': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample 
1691           is less than that of the normal distribution 
1692         * 'greater': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample 
1693           is greater than that of the normal distribution 
1694  
1695         .. versionadded:: 1.7.0 
1696  
1697     Returns 
1698     ------- 
1699     statistic : float 
1700         The computed z-score for this test. 
1701     pvalue : float 
1702         The p-value for the hypothesis test. 
1703  
1704     See Also 
1705     -------- 
1706     :ref:`hypothesis_kurtosistest` : Extended example 
1707  
1708     Notes 
1709     ----- 
1710     Valid only for n>20. This function uses the method described in [1]_. 
1711  
1712     References 
1713     ---------- 
1714     .. [1] F. J. Anscombe, W. J. Glynn, "Distribution of the kurtosis 
1715        statistic b2 for normal samples", Biometrika, vol. 70, pp. 227-234, 1983. 
1716  
1717     Examples 
1718     -------- 
1719  
1720     >>> import numpy as np 
1721     >>> from scipy.stats import kurtosistest 
1722     >>> kurtosistest(list(range(20))) 
1723     KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.08804338332528348) 
1724     >>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)), alternative='less') 
1725     KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.04402169166264174) 
1726     >>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)), alternative='greater') 
1727     KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.9559783083373583) 
1728     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng() 
1729     >>> s = rng.normal(0, 1, 1000) 
1730     >>> kurtosistest(s) 
1731     KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.475047944490622, pvalue=0.14019965402996987) 
1732  
1733     For a more detailed example, see :ref:`hypothesis_kurtosistest`. 
1734     """
1735     xp = array_namespace(a)
1736     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis, xp=xp)
1737 
1738     n = a.shape[axis]
1739 
1740     if n < 5:
1741         message = ("`kurtosistest` requires at least 5 observations; "
1742                    f"only {n=} observations were given.")
1743         raise ValueError(message)
1744     if n < 20:
1745         message = ("`kurtosistest` p-value may be inaccurate with fewer than 20 "
1746                    f"observations; only {n=} observations were given.")
1747         warnings.warn(message, stacklevel=2)
1748     b2 = kurtosis(a, axis, fisher=False, _no_deco=True)
1749 
1750     E = 3.0*(n-1) / (n+1)
1751     varb2 = 24.0*n*(n-2)*(n-3) / ((n+1)*(n+1.)*(n+3)*(n+5))  # [1]_ Eq. 1
1752     x = (b2-E) / varb2**0.5  # [1]_ Eq. 4
1753     # [1]_ Eq. 2:
1754     sqrtbeta1 = 6.0*(n*n-5*n+2)/((n+7)*(n+9)) * ((6.0*(n+3)*(n+5))
1755                                                  / (n*(n-2)*(n-3)))**0.5
1756     # [1]_ Eq. 3:
1757     A = 6.0 + 8.0/sqrtbeta1 * (2.0/sqrtbeta1 + (1+4.0/(sqrtbeta1**2))**0.5)
1758     term1 = 1 - 2/(9.0*A)
1759     denom = 1 + x * (2/(A-4.0))**0.5
1760     NaN = _get_nan(x, xp=xp)
1761     term2 = xp_sign(denom) * xp.where(denom == 0.0, NaN,
1762                                       ((1-2.0/A)/xp.abs(denom))**(1/3))
1763     if xp.any(denom == 0):
1764         msg = ("Test statistic not defined in some cases due to division by "
1765                "zero. Return nan in that case...")
1766         warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=2)
1767 
1768     Z = (term1 - term2) / (2/(9.0*A))**0.5  # [1]_ Eq. 5
1769 
1770     pvalue = _get_pvalue(Z, _SimpleNormal(), alternative, xp=xp)
1771 
1772     Z = Z[()] if Z.ndim == 0 else Z
1773     pvalue = pvalue[()] if pvalue.ndim == 0 else pvalue
1774     return KurtosistestResult(Z, pvalue)
1775 
1776 
1777 NormaltestResult = namedtuple('NormaltestResult', ('statistic', 'pvalue'))
1778 
1779 
1780 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(NormaltestResult, n_samples=1, too_small=7)
1781 def normaltest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'):
1782     r"""Test whether a sample differs from a normal distribution. 
1783  
1784     This function tests the null hypothesis that a sample comes 
1785     from a normal distribution.  It is based on D'Agostino and 
1786     Pearson's [1]_, [2]_ test that combines skew and kurtosis to 
1787     produce an omnibus test of normality. 
1788  
1789     Parameters 
1790     ---------- 
1791     a : array_like 
1792         The array containing the sample to be tested. Must contain 
1793         at least eight observations. 
1794     axis : int or None, optional 
1795         Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None, 
1796         compute over the whole array `a`. 
1797     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional 
1798         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
1799         The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
1800  
1801             * 'propagate': returns nan 
1802             * 'raise': throws an error 
1803             * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
1804  
1805     Returns 
1806     ------- 
1807     statistic : float or array 
1808         ``s^2 + k^2``, where ``s`` is the z-score returned by `skewtest` and 
1809         ``k`` is the z-score returned by `kurtosistest`. 
1810     pvalue : float or array 
1811         A 2-sided chi squared probability for the hypothesis test. 
1812  
1813     See Also 
1814     -------- 
1815     :ref:`hypothesis_normaltest` : Extended example 
1816  
1817     References 
1818     ---------- 
1819     .. [1] D'Agostino, R. B. (1971), "An omnibus test of normality for 
1820             moderate and large sample size", Biometrika, 58, 341-348 
1821     .. [2] D'Agostino, R. and Pearson, E. S. (1973), "Tests for departure from 
1822             normality", Biometrika, 60, 613-622 
1823  
1824     Examples 
1825     -------- 
1826  
1827     >>> import numpy as np 
1828     >>> from scipy import stats 
1829     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng() 
1830     >>> pts = 1000 
1831     >>> a = rng.normal(0, 1, size=pts) 
1832     >>> b = rng.normal(2, 1, size=pts) 
1833     >>> x = np.concatenate((a, b)) 
1834     >>> res = stats.normaltest(x) 
1835     >>> res.statistic 
1836     53.619...  # random 
1837     >>> res.pvalue 
1838     2.273917413209226e-12  # random 
1839  
1840     For a more detailed example, see :ref:`hypothesis_normaltest`. 
1841     """
1842     xp = array_namespace(a)
1843 
1844     s, _ = skewtest(a, axis, _no_deco=True)
1845     k, _ = kurtosistest(a, axis, _no_deco=True)
1846     statistic = s*s + k*k
1847 
1848     chi2 = _SimpleChi2(xp.asarray(2.))
1849     pvalue = _get_pvalue(statistic, chi2, alternative='greater', symmetric=False, xp=xp)
1850 
1851     statistic = statistic[()] if statistic.ndim == 0 else statistic
1852     pvalue = pvalue[()] if pvalue.ndim == 0 else pvalue
1853 
1854     return NormaltestResult(statistic, pvalue)
1855 
1856 
1857 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(SignificanceResult, default_axis=None)
1858 def jarque_bera(x, *, axis=None):
1859     r"""Perform the Jarque-Bera goodness of fit test on sample data. 
1860  
1861     The Jarque-Bera test tests whether the sample data has the skewness and 
1862     kurtosis matching a normal distribution. 
1863  
1864     Note that this test only works for a large enough number of data samples 
1865     (>2000) as the test statistic asymptotically has a Chi-squared distribution 
1866     with 2 degrees of freedom. 
1867  
1868     Parameters 
1869     ---------- 
1870     x : array_like 
1871         Observations of a random variable. 
1872     axis : int or None, default: 0 
1873         If an int, the axis of the input along which to compute the statistic. 
1874         The statistic of each axis-slice (e.g. row) of the input will appear in 
1875         a corresponding element of the output. 
1876         If ``None``, the input will be raveled before computing the statistic. 
1877  
1878     Returns 
1879     ------- 
1880     result : SignificanceResult 
1881         An object with the following attributes: 
1882  
1883         statistic : float 
1884             The test statistic. 
1885         pvalue : float 
1886             The p-value for the hypothesis test. 
1887  
1888     See Also 
1889     -------- 
1890     :ref:`hypothesis_jarque_bera` : Extended example 
1891  
1892     References 
1893     ---------- 
1894     .. [1] Jarque, C. and Bera, A. (1980) "Efficient tests for normality, 
1895            homoscedasticity and serial independence of regression residuals", 
1896            6 Econometric Letters 255-259. 
1897  
1898     Examples 
1899     -------- 
1900  
1901     >>> import numpy as np 
1902     >>> from scipy import stats 
1903     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng() 
1904     >>> x = rng.normal(0, 1, 100000) 
1905     >>> jarque_bera_test = stats.jarque_bera(x) 
1906     >>> jarque_bera_test 
1907     Jarque_beraResult(statistic=3.3415184718131554, pvalue=0.18810419594996775) 
1908     >>> jarque_bera_test.statistic 
1909     3.3415184718131554 
1910     >>> jarque_bera_test.pvalue 
1911     0.18810419594996775 
1912  
1913     For a more detailed example, see :ref:`hypothesis_jarque_bera`. 
1914     """
1915     xp = array_namespace(x)
1916     x = xp.asarray(x)
1917     if axis is None:
1918         x = xp.reshape(x, (-1,))
1919         axis = 0
1920 
1921     n = x.shape[axis]
1922     if n == 0:
1923         raise ValueError('At least one observation is required.')
1924 
1925     mu = xp.mean(x, axis=axis, keepdims=True)
1926     diffx = x - mu
1927     s = skew(diffx, axis=axis, _no_deco=True)
1928     k = kurtosis(diffx, axis=axis, _no_deco=True)
1929     statistic = n / 6 * (s**2 + k**2 / 4)
1930 
1931     chi2 = _SimpleChi2(xp.asarray(2.))
1932     pvalue = _get_pvalue(statistic, chi2, alternative='greater', symmetric=False, xp=xp)
1933 
1934     statistic = statistic[()] if statistic.ndim == 0 else statistic
1935     pvalue = pvalue[()] if pvalue.ndim == 0 else pvalue
1936 
1937     return SignificanceResult(statistic, pvalue)
1938 
1939 
1940 #####################################
1941 #        FREQUENCY FUNCTIONS        #
1942 #####################################
1943 
1944 
1945 def scoreatpercentile(a, per, limit=(), interpolation_method='fraction',
1946                       axis=None):
1947     """Calculate the score at a given percentile of the input sequence. 
1948  
1949     For example, the score at ``per=50`` is the median. If the desired quantile 
1950     lies between two data points, we interpolate between them, according to 
1951     the value of `interpolation`. If the parameter `limit` is provided, it 
1952     should be a tuple (lower, upper) of two values. 
1953  
1954     Parameters 
1955     ---------- 
1956     a : array_like 
1957         A 1-D array of values from which to extract score. 
1958     per : array_like 
1959         Percentile(s) at which to extract score.  Values should be in range 
1960         [0,100]. 
1961     limit : tuple, optional 
1962         Tuple of two scalars, the lower and upper limits within which to 
1963         compute the percentile. Values of `a` outside 
1964         this (closed) interval will be ignored. 
1965     interpolation_method : {'fraction', 'lower', 'higher'}, optional 
1966         Specifies the interpolation method to use, 
1967         when the desired quantile lies between two data points `i` and `j` 
1968         The following options are available (default is 'fraction'): 
1969  
1970           * 'fraction': ``i + (j - i) * fraction`` where ``fraction`` is the 
1971             fractional part of the index surrounded by ``i`` and ``j`` 
1972           * 'lower': ``i`` 
1973           * 'higher': ``j`` 
1974  
1975     axis : int, optional 
1976         Axis along which the percentiles are computed. Default is None. If 
1977         None, compute over the whole array `a`. 
1978  
1979     Returns 
1980     ------- 
1981     score : float or ndarray 
1982         Score at percentile(s). 
1983  
1984     See Also 
1985     -------- 
1986     percentileofscore, numpy.percentile 
1987  
1988     Notes 
1989     ----- 
1990     This function will become obsolete in the future. 
1991     For NumPy 1.9 and higher, `numpy.percentile` provides all the functionality 
1992     that `scoreatpercentile` provides.  And it's significantly faster. 
1993     Therefore it's recommended to use `numpy.percentile` for users that have 
1994     numpy >= 1.9. 
1995  
1996     Examples 
1997     -------- 
1998     >>> import numpy as np 
1999     >>> from scipy import stats 
2000     >>> a = np.arange(100) 
2001     >>> stats.scoreatpercentile(a, 50) 
2002     49.5 
2003  
2004     """
2005     # adapted from NumPy's percentile function.  When we require numpy >= 1.8,
2006     # the implementation of this function can be replaced by np.percentile.
2007     a = np.asarray(a)
2008     if a.size == 0:
2009         # empty array, return nan(s) with shape matching `per`
2010         if np.isscalar(per):
2011             return np.nan
2012         else:
2013             return np.full(np.asarray(per).shape, np.nan, dtype=np.float64)
2014 
2015     if limit:
2016         a = a[(limit[0] <= a) & (a <= limit[1])]
2017 
2018     sorted_ = np.sort(a, axis=axis)
2019     if axis is None:
2020         axis = 0
2021 
2022     return _compute_qth_percentile(sorted_, per, interpolation_method, axis)
2023 
2024 
2025 # handle sequence of per's without calling sort multiple times
2026 def _compute_qth_percentile(sorted_, per, interpolation_method, axis):
2027     if not np.isscalar(per):
2028         score = [_compute_qth_percentile(sorted_, i,
2029                                          interpolation_method, axis)
2030                  for i in per]
2031         return np.array(score)
2032 
2033     if not (0 <= per <= 100):
2034         raise ValueError("percentile must be in the range [0, 100]")
2035 
2036     indexer = [slice(None)] * sorted_.ndim
2037     idx = per / 100. * (sorted_.shape[axis] - 1)
2038 
2039     if int(idx) != idx:
2040         # round fractional indices according to interpolation method
2041         if interpolation_method == 'lower':
2042             idx = int(np.floor(idx))
2043         elif interpolation_method == 'higher':
2044             idx = int(np.ceil(idx))
2045         elif interpolation_method == 'fraction':
2046             pass  # keep idx as fraction and interpolate
2047         else:
2048             raise ValueError("interpolation_method can only be 'fraction', "
2049                              "'lower' or 'higher'")
2050 
2051     i = int(idx)
2052     if i == idx:
2053         indexer[axis] = slice(i, i + 1)
2054         weights = array(1)
2055         sumval = 1.0
2056     else:
2057         indexer[axis] = slice(i, i + 2)
2058         j = i + 1
2059         weights = array([(j - idx), (idx - i)], float)
2060         wshape = [1] * sorted_.ndim
2061         wshape[axis] = 2
2062         weights.shape = wshape
2063         sumval = weights.sum()
2064 
2065     # Use np.add.reduce (== np.sum but a little faster) to coerce data type
2066     return np.add.reduce(sorted_[tuple(indexer)] * weights, axis=axis) / sumval
2067 
2068 
2069 def percentileofscore(a, score, kind='rank', nan_policy='propagate'):
2070     """Compute the percentile rank of a score relative to a list of scores. 
2071  
2072     A `percentileofscore` of, for example, 80% means that 80% of the
