9328     is equal to 0.5. We choose a confidence level of 99%; that is, we will 
9329     reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative if the p-value is 
9330     less than 0.01. 
9331  
9332     When testing random variates from the standard uniform distribution, which 
9333     has a median of 0.5, we expect the data to be consistent with the null 
9334     hypothesis most of the time. 
9335  
9336     >>> import numpy as np 
9337     >>> from scipy import stats 
9338     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng(6981396440634228121) 
9339     >>> rvs = stats.uniform.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng) 
9340     >>> stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=0.5, p=0.5) 
9341     QuantileTestResult(statistic=45, statistic_type=1, pvalue=0.36820161732669576) 
9342  
9343     As expected, the p-value is not below our threshold of 0.01, so 
9344     we cannot reject the null hypothesis. 
9345  
9346     When testing data from the standard *normal* distribution, which has a 
9347     median of 0, we would expect the null hypothesis to be rejected. 
9348  
9349     >>> rvs = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng) 
9350     >>> stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=0.5, p=0.5) 
9351     QuantileTestResult(statistic=67, statistic_type=2, pvalue=0.0008737198369123724) 
9352  
9353     Indeed, the p-value is lower than our threshold of 0.01, so we reject the 
9354     null hypothesis in favor of the default "two-sided" alternative: the median 
9355     of the population is *not* equal to 0.5. 
9356  
9357     However, suppose we were to test the null hypothesis against the 
9358     one-sided alternative that the median of the population is *greater* than 
9359     0.5. Since the median of the standard normal is less than 0.5, we would not 
9360     expect the null hypothesis to be rejected. 
9361  
9362     >>> stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=0.5, p=0.5, alternative='greater') 
9363     QuantileTestResult(statistic=67, statistic_type=1, pvalue=0.9997956114162866) 
9364  
9365     Unsurprisingly, with a p-value greater than our threshold, we would not 
9366     reject the null hypothesis in favor of the chosen alternative. 
9367  
9368     The quantile test can be used for any quantile, not only the median. For 
9369     example, we can test whether the third quartile of the distribution 
9370     underlying the sample is greater than 0.6. 
9371  
9372     >>> rvs = stats.uniform.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng) 
9373     >>> stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=0.6, p=0.75, alternative='greater') 
9374     QuantileTestResult(statistic=64, statistic_type=1, pvalue=0.00940696592998271) 
9375  
9376     The p-value is lower than the threshold. We reject the null hypothesis in 
9377     favor of the alternative: the third quartile of the distribution underlying 
9378     our sample is greater than 0.6. 
9379  
9380     `quantile_test` can also compute confidence intervals for any quantile. 
9381  
9382     >>> rvs = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng) 
9383     >>> res = stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=0.6, p=0.75) 
9384     >>> ci = res.confidence_interval(confidence_level=0.95) 
9385     >>> ci 
9386     ConfidenceInterval(low=0.284491604437432, high=0.8912531024914844) 
9387  
9388     When testing a one-sided alternative, the confidence interval contains 
9389     all observations such that if passed as `q`, the p-value of the 
9390     test would be greater than 0.05, and therefore the null hypothesis 
9391     would not be rejected. For example: 
9392  
9393     >>> rvs.sort() 
9394     >>> q, p, alpha = 0.6, 0.75, 0.95 
9395     >>> res = stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=q, p=p, alternative='less') 
9396     >>> ci = res.confidence_interval(confidence_level=alpha) 
9397     >>> for x in rvs[rvs <= ci.high]: 
9398     ...     res = stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=x, p=p, alternative='less') 
9399     ...     assert res.pvalue > 1-alpha 
9400     >>> for x in rvs[rvs > ci.high]: 
9401     ...     res = stats.quantile_test(rvs, q=x, p=p, alternative='less') 
9402     ...     assert res.pvalue < 1-alpha 
9403  
9404     Also, if a 95% confidence interval is repeatedly generated for random 
9405     samples, the confidence interval will contain the true quantile value in 
9406     approximately 95% of replications. 
9407  
9408     >>> dist = stats.rayleigh() # our "unknown" distribution 
9409     >>> p = 0.2 
9410     >>> true_stat = dist.ppf(p) # the true value of the statistic 
9411     >>> n_trials = 1000 
9412     >>> quantile_ci_contains_true_stat = 0 
9413     >>> for i in range(n_trials): 
9414     ...     data = dist.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng) 
9415     ...     res = stats.quantile_test(data, p=p) 
9416     ...     ci = res.confidence_interval(0.95) 
9417     ...     if ci[0] < true_stat < ci[1]: 
9418     ...         quantile_ci_contains_true_stat += 1 
9419     >>> quantile_ci_contains_true_stat >= 950 
9420     True 
9421  
9422     This works with any distribution and any quantile, as long as the samples 
9423     are i.i.d. 
9424     """
9425     # Implementation carefully follows [1] 3.2
9426     # "H0: the p*th quantile of X is x*"
9427     # To facilitate comparison with [1], we'll use variable names that
9428     # best match Conover's notation
9429     X, x_star, p_star, H1 = quantile_test_iv(x, q, p, alternative)
9430 
9431     # "We will use two test statistics in this test. Let T1 equal "
9432     # "the number of observations less than or equal to x*, and "
9433     # "let T2 equal the number of observations less than x*."
9434     T1 = (X <= x_star).sum()
9435     T2 = (X < x_star).sum()
9436 
9437     # "The null distribution of the test statistics T1 and T2 is "
9438     # "the binomial distribution, with parameters n = sample size, and "
9439     # "p = p* as given in the null hypothesis.... Y has the binomial "
9440     # "distribution with parameters n and p*."
9441     n = len(X)
9442     Y = stats.binom(n=n, p=p_star)
9443 
9444     # "H1: the p* population quantile is less than x*"
9445     if H1 == 'less':
9446         # "The p-value is the probability that a binomial random variable Y "
9447         # "is greater than *or equal to* the observed value of T2...using p=p*"
9448         pvalue = Y.sf(T2-1)  # Y.pmf(T2) + Y.sf(T2)
9449         statistic = T2
9450         statistic_type = 2
9451     # "H1: the p* population quantile is greater than x*"
9452     elif H1 == 'greater':
9453         # "The p-value is the probability that a binomial random variable Y "
9454         # "is less than or equal to the observed value of T1... using p = p*"
9455         pvalue = Y.cdf(T1)
9456         statistic = T1
9457         statistic_type = 1
9458     # "H1: x* is not the p*th population quantile"
9459     elif H1 == 'two-sided':
9460         # "The p-value is twice the smaller of the probabilities that a
9461         # binomial random variable Y is less than or equal to the observed
9462         # value of T1 or greater than or equal to the observed value of T2
9463         # using p=p*."
9464         # Note: both one-sided p-values can exceed 0.5 for the same data, so
9465         # `clip`
9466         pvalues = [Y.cdf(T1), Y.sf(T2 - 1)]  # [greater, less]
9467         sorted_idx = np.argsort(pvalues)
9468         pvalue = np.clip(2*pvalues[sorted_idx[0]], 0, 1)
9469         if sorted_idx[0]:
9470             statistic, statistic_type = T2, 2
9471         else:
9472             statistic, statistic_type = T1, 1
9473 
9474     return QuantileTestResult(
9475         statistic=statistic,
9476         statistic_type=statistic_type,
9477         pvalue=pvalue,
9478         _alternative=H1,
9479         _x=X,
9480         _p=p_star
9481     )
9482 
9483 
9484 #####################################
9485 #       STATISTICAL DISTANCES       #
9486 #####################################
9487 
9488 
9489 def wasserstein_distance_nd(u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None):
9490     r""" 
9491     Compute the Wasserstein-1 distance between two N-D discrete distributions. 
9492  
9493     The Wasserstein distance, also called the Earth mover's distance or the 
9494     optimal transport distance, is a similarity metric between two probability 
9495     distributions [1]_. In the discrete case, the Wasserstein distance can be 
9496     understood as the cost of an optimal transport plan to convert one 
9497     distribution into the other. The cost is calculated as the product of the 
9498     amount of probability mass being moved and the distance it is being moved. 
9499     A brief and intuitive introduction can be found at [2]_. 
9500  
9501     .. versionadded:: 1.13.0 
9502  
9503     Parameters 
9504     ---------- 
9505     u_values : 2d array_like 
9506         A sample from a probability distribution or the support (set of all 
9507         possible values) of a probability distribution. Each element along 
9508         axis 0 is an observation or possible value, and axis 1 represents the 
9509         dimensionality of the distribution; i.e., each row is a vector 
9510         observation or possible value. 
9511  
9512     v_values : 2d array_like 
9513         A sample from or the support of a second distribution. 
9514  
9515     u_weights, v_weights : 1d array_like, optional 
9516         Weights or counts corresponding with the sample or probability masses 
9517         corresponding with the support values. Sum of elements must be positive 
9518         and finite. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same weight. 
9519  
9520     Returns 
9521     ------- 
9522     distance : float 
9523         The computed distance between the distributions. 
9524  
9525     Notes 
9526     ----- 
9527     Given two probability mass functions, :math:`u` 
9528     and :math:`v`, the first Wasserstein distance between the distributions 
9529     using the Euclidean norm is: 
9530  
9531     .. math:: 
9532  
9533         l_1 (u, v) = \inf_{\pi \in \Gamma (u, v)} \int \| x-y \|_2 \mathrm{d} \pi (x, y) 
9534  
9535     where :math:`\Gamma (u, v)` is the set of (probability) distributions on 
9536     :math:`\mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{R}^n` whose marginals are :math:`u` and 
9537     :math:`v` on the first and second factors respectively. For a given value 
9538     :math:`x`, :math:`u(x)` gives the probability of :math:`u` at position 
9539     :math:`x`, and the same for :math:`v(x)`. 
9540  
9541     This is also called the optimal transport problem or the Monge problem. 
9542     Let the finite point sets :math:`\{x_i\}` and :math:`\{y_j\}` denote 
9543     the support set of probability mass function :math:`u` and :math:`v` 
9544     respectively. The Monge problem can be expressed as follows, 
9545  
9546     Let :math:`\Gamma` denote the transport plan, :math:`D` denote the 
9547     distance matrix and, 
9548  
9549     .. math:: 
9550  
9551         x = \text{vec}(\Gamma)          \\ 
9552         c = \text{vec}(D)               \\ 
9553         b = \begin{bmatrix} 
9554                 u\\ 
9555                 v\\ 
9556             \end{bmatrix} 
9557  
9558     The :math:`\text{vec}()` function denotes the Vectorization function 
9559     that transforms a matrix into a column vector by vertically stacking 
9560     the columns of the matrix. 
9561     The transport plan :math:`\Gamma` is a matrix :math:`[\gamma_{ij}]` in 
9562     which :math:`\gamma_{ij}` is a positive value representing the amount of 
9563     probability mass transported from :math:`u(x_i)` to :math:`v(y_i)`. 
9564     Summing over the rows of :math:`\Gamma` should give the source distribution 
9565     :math:`u` : :math:`\sum_j \gamma_{ij} = u(x_i)` holds for all :math:`i` 
9566     and summing over the columns of :math:`\Gamma` should give the target 
9567     distribution :math:`v`: :math:`\sum_i \gamma_{ij} = v(y_j)` holds for all 
9568     :math:`j`. 
9569     The distance matrix :math:`D` is a matrix :math:`[d_{ij}]`, in which 
9570     :math:`d_{ij} = d(x_i, y_j)`. 
9571  
9572     Given :math:`\Gamma`, :math:`D`, :math:`b`, the Monge problem can be 
9573     transformed into a linear programming problem by 
9574     taking :math:`A x = b` as constraints and :math:`z = c^T x` as minimization 
9575     target (sum of costs) , where matrix :math:`A` has the form 
9576  
9577     .. math:: 
9578  
9579         \begin{array} {rrrr|rrrr|r|rrrr} 
9580             1 & 1 & \dots & 1 & 0 & 0 & \dots & 0 & \dots & 0 & 0 & \dots & 
9581                 0 \cr 
9582             0 & 0 & \dots & 0 & 1 & 1 & \dots & 1 & \dots & 0 & 0 &\dots & 
9583                 0 \cr 
9584             \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots 
9585                 & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots  \cr 
9586             0 & 0 & \dots & 0 & 0 & 0 & \dots & 0 & \dots & 1 & 1 & \dots & 
9587                 1 \cr \hline 
9588  
9589             1 & 0 & \dots & 0 & 1 & 0 & \dots & \dots & \dots & 1 & 0 & \dots & 
9590                 0 \cr 
9591             0 & 1 & \dots & 0 & 0 & 1 & \dots & \dots & \dots & 0 & 1 & \dots & 
9592                 0 \cr 
9593             \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & 
9594                 \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \cr 
9595             0 & 0 & \dots & 1 & 0 & 0 & \dots & 1 & \dots & 0 & 0 & \dots & 1 
9596         \end{array} 
9597  
9598     By solving the dual form of the above linear programming problem (with 
9599     solution :math:`y^*`), the Wasserstein distance :math:`l_1 (u, v)` can 
9600     be computed as :math:`b^T y^*`. 
9601  
9602     The above solution is inspired by Vincent Herrmann's blog [3]_ . For a 
9603     more thorough explanation, see [4]_ . 
9604  
9605     The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples 
9606     whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as 
9607     generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta 
9608     functions located at the specified values. 
9609  
9610     References 
9611     ---------- 
9612     .. [1] "Wasserstein metric", 
9613            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wasserstein_metric 
9614     .. [2] Lili Weng, "What is Wasserstein distance?", Lil'log, 
9615            https://lilianweng.github.io/posts/2017-08-20-gan/#what-is-wasserstein-distance. 
9616     .. [3] Hermann, Vincent. "Wasserstein GAN and the Kantorovich-Rubinstein 
9617            Duality". https://vincentherrmann.github.io/blog/wasserstein/. 
9618     .. [4] Peyré, Gabriel, and Marco Cuturi. "Computational optimal 
9619            transport." Center for Research in Economics and Statistics 
9620            Working Papers 2017-86 (2017). 
9621  
9622     See Also 
9623     -------- 
9624     wasserstein_distance: Compute the Wasserstein-1 distance between two 
9625         1D discrete distributions. 
9626  
9627     Examples 
9628     -------- 
9629     Compute the Wasserstein distance between two three-dimensional samples, 
9630     each with two observations. 
9631  
9632     >>> from scipy.stats import wasserstein_distance_nd 
9633     >>> wasserstein_distance_nd([[0, 2, 3], [1, 2, 5]], [[3, 2, 3], [4, 2, 5]]) 
9634     3.0 
9635  
9636     Compute the Wasserstein distance between two two-dimensional distributions 
9637     with three and two weighted observations, respectively. 
9638  
9639     >>> wasserstein_distance_nd([[0, 2.75], [2, 209.3], [0, 0]], 
9640     ...                      [[0.2, 0.322], [4.5, 25.1808]], 
9641     ...                      [0.4, 5.2, 0.114], [0.8, 1.5]) 
9642     174.15840245217169 
9643     """
9644     m, n = len(u_values), len(v_values)
9645     u_values = asarray(u_values)
9646     v_values = asarray(v_values)
9647 
9648     if u_values.ndim > 2 or v_values.ndim > 2:
9649         raise ValueError('Invalid input values. The inputs must have either '
9650                          'one or two dimensions.')
9651     # if dimensions are not equal throw error
9652     if u_values.ndim != v_values.ndim:
9653         raise ValueError('Invalid input values. Dimensions of inputs must be '
9654                          'equal.')
9655     # if data is 1D then call the cdf_distance function
9656     if u_values.ndim == 1 and v_values.ndim == 1:
9657         return _cdf_distance(1, u_values, v_values, u_weights, v_weights)
9658 
9659     u_values, u_weights = _validate_distribution(u_values, u_weights)
9660     v_values, v_weights = _validate_distribution(v_values, v_weights)
9661     # if number of columns is not equal throw error
9662     if u_values.shape[1] != v_values.shape[1]:
9663         raise ValueError('Invalid input values. If two-dimensional, '
9664                          '`u_values` and `v_values` must have the same '
9665                          'number of columns.')
9666 
9667     # if data contains np.inf then return inf or nan
9668     if np.any(np.isinf(u_values)) ^ np.any(np.isinf(v_values)):
9669         return np.inf
9670     elif np.any(np.isinf(u_values)) and np.any(np.isinf(v_values)):
9671         return np.nan
9672 
9673     # create constraints
9674     A_upper_part = sparse.block_diag((np.ones((1, n)), ) * m)
9675     A_lower_part = sparse.hstack((sparse.eye(n), ) * m)
9676     # sparse constraint matrix of size (m + n)*(m * n)
9677     A = sparse.vstack((A_upper_part, A_lower_part))
9678     A = sparse.coo_array(A)
9679 
9680     # get cost matrix
9681     D = distance_matrix(u_values, v_values, p=2)
9682     cost = D.ravel()
9683 
9684     # create the minimization target
9685     p_u = np.full(m, 1/m) if u_weights is None else u_weights/np.sum(u_weights)
9686     p_v = np.full(n, 1/n) if v_weights is None else v_weights/np.sum(v_weights)
9687     b = np.concatenate((p_u, p_v), axis=0)
9688 
9689     # solving LP
9690     constraints = LinearConstraint(A=A.T, ub=cost)
9691     opt_res = milp(c=-b, constraints=constraints, bounds=(-np.inf, np.inf))
9692     return -opt_res.fun
9693 
9694 
9695 def wasserstein_distance(u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None):
9696     r""" 
9697     Compute the Wasserstein-1 distance between two 1D discrete distributions. 
9698  
9699     The Wasserstein distance, also called the Earth mover's distance or the 
9700     optimal transport distance, is a similarity metric between two probability 
9701     distributions [1]_. In the discrete case, the Wasserstein distance can be 
9702     understood as the cost of an optimal transport plan to convert one 
9703     distribution into the other. The cost is calculated as the product of the 
9704     amount of probability mass being moved and the distance it is being moved. 
9705     A brief and intuitive introduction can be found at [2]_. 
9706  
9707     .. versionadded:: 1.0.0 
9708  
9709     Parameters 
9710     ---------- 
9711     u_values : 1d array_like 
9712         A sample from a probability distribution or the support (set of all 
9713         possible values) of a probability distribution. Each element is an 
9714         observation or possible value. 
9715  
9716     v_values : 1d array_like 
9717         A sample from or the support of a second distribution. 
9718  
9719     u_weights, v_weights : 1d array_like, optional 
9720         Weights or counts corresponding with the sample or probability masses 
9721         corresponding with the support values. Sum of elements must be positive 
9722         and finite. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same weight. 
9723  
9724     Returns 
9725     ------- 
9726     distance : float 
9727         The computed distance between the distributions. 
9728  
9729     Notes 
9730     ----- 
9731     Given two 1D probability mass functions, :math:`u` and :math:`v`, the first 
9732     Wasserstein distance between the distributions is: 
9733  
9734     .. math:: 
9735  
9736         l_1 (u, v) = \inf_{\pi \in \Gamma (u, v)} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times 
9737         \mathbb{R}} |x-y| \mathrm{d} \pi (x, y) 
9738  
9739     where :math:`\Gamma (u, v)` is the set of (probability) distributions on 
9740     :math:`\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}` whose marginals are :math:`u` and 
9741     :math:`v` on the first and second factors respectively. For a given value 
9742     :math:`x`, :math:`u(x)` gives the probability of :math:`u` at position 
9743     :math:`x`, and the same for :math:`v(x)`. 
9744  
9745     If :math:`U` and :math:`V` are the respective CDFs of :math:`u` and 
9746     :math:`v`, this distance also equals to: 
9747  
9748     .. math:: 
9749  
9750         l_1(u, v) = \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} |U-V| 
9751  
9752     See [3]_ for a proof of the equivalence of both definitions. 
9753  
9754     The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples 
9755     whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as 
9756     generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta 
9757     functions located at the specified values. 
9758  
9759     References 
9760     ---------- 
9761     .. [1] "Wasserstein metric", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wasserstein_metric 
9762     .. [2] Lili Weng, "What is Wasserstein distance?", Lil'log, 
9763            https://lilianweng.github.io/posts/2017-08-20-gan/#what-is-wasserstein-distance. 
9764     .. [3] Ramdas, Garcia, Cuturi "On Wasserstein Two Sample Testing and Related 
9765            Families of Nonparametric Tests" (2015). :arXiv:`1509.02237`. 
9766  
9767     See Also 
9768     -------- 
9769     wasserstein_distance_nd: Compute the Wasserstein-1 distance between two N-D 
9770         discrete distributions. 
9771  
9772     Examples 
9773     -------- 
9774     >>> from scipy.stats import wasserstein_distance 
9775     >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1, 3], [5, 6, 8]) 
9776     5.0 
9777     >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1], [0, 1], [3, 1], [2, 2]) 
9778     0.25 
9779     >>> wasserstein_distance([3.4, 3.9, 7.5, 7.8], [4.5, 1.4], 
9780     ...                      [1.4, 0.9, 3.1, 7.2], [3.2, 3.5]) 
9781     4.0781331438047861 
9782  
9783     """
9784     return _cdf_distance(1, u_values, v_values, u_weights, v_weights)
9785 
9786 
9787 def energy_distance(u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None):
9788     r"""Compute the energy distance between two 1D distributions. 
9789  
9790     .. versionadded:: 1.0.0 
9791  
9792     Parameters 
9793     ---------- 
9794     u_values, v_values : array_like 
9795         Values observed in the (empirical) distribution. 
9796     u_weights, v_weights : array_like, optional 
9797         Weight for each value. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same 
9798         weight. 
9799         `u_weights` (resp. `v_weights`) must have the same length as 
9800         `u_values` (resp. `v_values`). If the weight sum differs from 1, it 
9801         must still be positive and finite so that the weights can be normalized 
9802         to sum to 1. 
9803  
9804     Returns 
9805     ------- 
9806     distance : float 
9807         The computed distance between the distributions. 
9808  
9809     Notes 
9810     ----- 
9811     The energy distance between two distributions :math:`u` and :math:`v`, whose 
9812     respective CDFs are :math:`U` and :math:`V`, equals to: 
9813  
9814     .. math:: 
9815  
9816         D(u, v) = \left( 2\mathbb E|X - Y| - \mathbb E|X - X'| - 
9817         \mathbb E|Y - Y'| \right)^{1/2} 
9818  
9819     where :math:`X` and :math:`X'` (resp. :math:`Y` and :math:`Y'`) are 
9820     independent random variables whose probability distribution is :math:`u` 
9821     (resp. :math:`v`). 
9822  
9823     Sometimes the square of this quantity is referred to as the "energy 
9824     distance" (e.g. in [2]_, [4]_), but as noted in [1]_ and [3]_, only the 
9825     definition above satisfies the axioms of a distance function (metric). 
9826  
9827     As shown in [2]_, for one-dimensional real-valued variables, the energy 
9828     distance is linked to the non-distribution-free version of the Cramér-von 
9829     Mises distance: 
9830  
9831     .. math:: 
9832  
9833         D(u, v) = \sqrt{2} l_2(u, v) = \left( 2 \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} (U-V)^2 
9834         \right)^{1/2} 
9835  
9836     Note that the common Cramér-von Mises criterion uses the distribution-free 
9837     version of the distance. See [2]_ (section 2), for more details about both 
9838     versions of the distance. 
9839  
9840     The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples 
9841     whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as 
9842     generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta 
9843     functions located at the specified values. 
9844  
9845     References 
9846     ---------- 
9847     .. [1] Rizzo, Szekely "Energy distance." Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: 
9848            Computational Statistics, 8(1):27-38 (2015). 
9849     .. [2] Szekely "E-statistics: The energy of statistical samples." Bowling 
9850            Green State University, Department of Mathematics and Statistics, 
9851            Technical Report 02-16 (2002). 
9852     .. [3] "Energy distance", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_distance 
9853     .. [4] Bellemare, Danihelka, Dabney, Mohamed, Lakshminarayanan, Hoyer, 
9854            Munos "The Cramer Distance as a Solution to Biased Wasserstein 
9855            Gradients" (2017). :arXiv:`1705.10743`. 
9856  
9857     Examples 
9858     -------- 
9859     >>> from scipy.stats import energy_distance 
9860     >>> energy_distance([0], [2]) 
9861     2.0000000000000004 
9862     >>> energy_distance([0, 8], [0, 8], [3, 1], [2, 2]) 
9863     1.0000000000000002 
9864     >>> energy_distance([0.7, 7.4, 2.4, 6.8], [1.4, 8. ], 
9865     ...                 [2.1, 4.2, 7.4, 8. ], [7.6, 8.8]) 
9866     0.88003340976158217 
9867  
9868     """
9869     return np.sqrt(2) * _cdf_distance(2, u_values, v_values,
9870                                       u_weights, v_weights)
9871 
9872 
9873 def _cdf_distance(p, u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None):
9874     r""" 
9875     Compute, between two one-dimensional distributions :math:`u` and 
9876     :math:`v`, whose respective CDFs are :math:`U` and :math:`V`, the 
9877     statistical distance that is defined as: 
9878  
9879     .. math:: 
9880  
9881         l_p(u, v) = \left( \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} |U-V|^p \right)^{1/p} 
9882  
9883     p is a positive parameter; p = 1 gives the Wasserstein distance, p = 2 
9884     gives the energy distance. 
9885  
9886     Parameters 
9887     ---------- 
9888     u_values, v_values : array_like 
9889         Values observed in the (empirical) distribution. 
9890     u_weights, v_weights : array_like, optional 
9891         Weight for each value. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same 
9892         weight. 
9893         `u_weights` (resp. `v_weights`) must have the same length as 
9894         `u_values` (resp. `v_values`). If the weight sum differs from 1, it 
9895         must still be positive and finite so that the weights can be normalized 
9896         to sum to 1. 
9897  
9898     Returns 
9899     ------- 
9900     distance : float 
9901         The computed distance between the distributions. 
9902  
9903     Notes 
9904     ----- 
9905     The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples 
9906     whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as 
9907     generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta 
9908     functions located at the specified values. 
9909  
9910     References 
9911     ---------- 
9912     .. [1] Bellemare, Danihelka, Dabney, Mohamed, Lakshminarayanan, Hoyer, 
9913            Munos "The Cramer Distance as a Solution to Biased Wasserstein 
9914            Gradients" (2017). :arXiv:`1705.10743`. 
9915  
9916     """
9917     u_values, u_weights = _validate_distribution(u_values, u_weights)
9918     v_values, v_weights = _validate_distribution(v_values, v_weights)
9919 
9920     u_sorter = np.argsort(u_values)
9921     v_sorter = np.argsort(v_values)
9922 
9923     all_values = np.concatenate((u_values, v_values))
9924     all_values.sort(kind='mergesort')
9925 
9926     # Compute the differences between pairs of successive values of u and v.
9927     deltas = np.diff(all_values)
9928 
9929     # Get the respective positions of the values of u and v among the values of
9930     # both distributions.
9931     u_cdf_indices = u_values[u_sorter].searchsorted(all_values[:-1], 'right')
9932     v_cdf_indices = v_values[v_sorter].searchsorted(all_values[:-1], 'right')
9933 
9934     # Calculate the CDFs of u and v using their weights, if specified.
9935     if u_weights is None:
9936         u_cdf = u_cdf_indices / u_values.size
9937     else:
9938         u_sorted_cumweights = np.concatenate(([0],
9939                                               np.cumsum(u_weights[u_sorter])))
9940         u_cdf = u_sorted_cumweights[u_cdf_indices] / u_sorted_cumweights[-1]
9941 
9942     if v_weights is None:
9943         v_cdf = v_cdf_indices / v_values.size
9944     else:
9945         v_sorted_cumweights = np.concatenate(([0],
9946                                               np.cumsum(v_weights[v_sorter])))
9947         v_cdf = v_sorted_cumweights[v_cdf_indices] / v_sorted_cumweights[-1]
9948 
9949     # Compute the value of the integral based on the CDFs.
9950     # If p = 1 or p = 2, we avoid using np.power, which introduces an overhead
9951     # of about 15%.
9952     if p == 1:
9953         return np.sum(np.multiply(np.abs(u_cdf - v_cdf), deltas))
9954     if p == 2:
9955         return np.sqrt(np.sum(np.multiply(np.square(u_cdf - v_cdf), deltas)))
9956     return np.power(np.sum(np.multiply(np.power(np.abs(u_cdf - v_cdf), p),
9957                                        deltas)), 1/p)
9958 
9959 
9960 def _validate_distribution(values, weights):
9961     """ 
9962     Validate the values and weights from a distribution input of `cdf_distance` 
9963     and return them as ndarray objects. 
9964  
9965     Parameters 
9966     ---------- 
9967     values : array_like 
9968         Values observed in the (empirical) distribution. 
9969     weights : array_like 
9970         Weight for each value. 
9971  
9972     Returns 
9973     ------- 
9974     values : ndarray 
9975         Values as ndarray. 
9976     weights : ndarray 
9977         Weights as ndarray. 
9978  
9979     """
9980     # Validate the value array.
9981     values = np.asarray(values, dtype=float)
9982     if len(values) == 0:
9983         raise ValueError("Distribution can't be empty.")
9984 
9985     # Validate the weight array, if specified.
9986     if weights is not None:
9987         weights = np.asarray(weights, dtype=float)
9988         if len(weights) != len(values):
9989             raise ValueError('Value and weight array-likes for the same '
9990                              'empirical distribution must be of the same size.')
9991         if np.any(weights < 0):
9992             raise ValueError('All weights must be non-negative.')
9993         if not 0 < np.sum(weights) < np.inf:
9994             raise ValueError('Weight array-like sum must be positive and '
9995                              'finite. Set as None for an equal distribution of '
9996                              'weight.')
9997 
9998         return values, weights
9999 
10000     return values, None
10001 
10002 
10003 #####################################
10004 #         SUPPORT FUNCTIONS         #
10005 #####################################
10006 
10007 RepeatedResults = namedtuple('RepeatedResults', ('values', 'counts'))
10008 
10009 
10010 @_deprecated("`scipy.stats.find_repeats` is deprecated as of SciPy 1.15.0 "
10011              "and will be removed in SciPy 1.17.0. Please use "
10012              "`numpy.unique`/`numpy.unique_counts` instead.")
10013 def find_repeats(arr):
10014     """Find repeats and repeat counts. 
10015  
10016     .. deprecated:: 1.15.0 
10017  
10018         This function is deprecated as of SciPy 1.15.0 and will be removed 
10019         in SciPy 1.17.0. Please use `numpy.unique` / `numpy.unique_counts` instead. 
10020  
10021     Parameters 
10022     ---------- 
10023     arr : array_like 
10024         Input array. This is cast to float64. 
10025  
10026     Returns 
10027     ------- 
10028     values : ndarray 
10029         The unique values from the (flattened) input that are repeated. 
10030  
10031     counts : ndarray 
10032         Number of times the corresponding 'value' is repeated. 
10033  
10034     Notes 
10035     ----- 
10036     In numpy >= 1.9 `numpy.unique` provides similar functionality. The main 
10037     difference is that `find_repeats` only returns repeated values. 
10038  
10039     Examples 
10040     -------- 
10041     >>> from scipy import stats 
10042     >>> stats.find_repeats([2, 1, 2, 3, 2, 2, 5]) 
10043     RepeatedResults(values=array([2.]), counts=array([4])) 
10044  
10045     >>> stats.find_repeats([[10, 20, 1, 2], [5, 5, 4, 4]]) 
10046     RepeatedResults(values=array([4.,  5.]), counts=array([2, 2])) 
10047  
10048     """
10049     # Note: always copies.
10050     return RepeatedResults(*_find_repeats(np.array(arr, dtype=np.float64)))
10051 
10052 
10053 def _sum_of_squares(a, axis=0):
10054     """Square each element of the input array, and return the sum(s) of that. 
10055  
10056     Parameters 
10057     ---------- 
10058     a : array_like 
10059         Input array. 
10060     axis : int or None, optional 
10061         Axis along which to calculate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 
10062         the whole array `a`. 
10063  
10064     Returns 
10065     ------- 
10066     sum_of_squares : ndarray 
10067         The sum along the given axis for (a**2). 
10068  
10069     See Also 
10070     -------- 
10071     _square_of_sums : The square(s) of the sum(s) (the opposite of 
10072         `_sum_of_squares`). 
10073  
10074     """
10075     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis)
10076     return np.sum(a*a, axis)
10077 
10078 
10079 def _square_of_sums(a, axis=0):
10080     """Sum elements of the input array, and return the square(s) of that sum. 
10081  
10082     Parameters 
10083     ---------- 
10084     a : array_like 
10085         Input array. 
10086     axis : int or None, optional 
10087         Axis along which to calculate. Default is 0. If None, compute over 
10088         the whole array `a`. 
10089  
10090     Returns 
10091     ------- 
10092     square_of_sums : float or ndarray 
10093         The square of the sum over `axis`. 
10094  
10095     See Also 
10096     -------- 
10097     _sum_of_squares : The sum of squares (the opposite of `square_of_sums`). 
10098  
10099     """
10100     a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis)
10101     s = np.sum(a, axis)
10102     if not np.isscalar(s):
10103         return s.astype(float) * s
10104     else:
10105         return float(s) * s
10106 
10107 
10108 def rankdata(a, method='average', *, axis=None, nan_policy='propagate'):
10109     """Assign ranks to data, dealing with ties appropriately. 
10110  
10111     By default (``axis=None``), the data array is first flattened, and a flat 
10112     array of ranks is returned. Separately reshape the rank array to the 
10113     shape of the data array if desired (see Examples). 
10114  
10115     Ranks begin at 1.  The `method` argument controls how ranks are assigned 
10116     to equal values.  See [1]_ for further discussion of ranking methods. 
10117  
10118     Parameters 
10119     ---------- 
10120     a : array_like 
10121         The array of values to be ranked. 
10122     method : {'average', 'min', 'max', 'dense', 'ordinal'}, optional 
10123         The method used to assign ranks to tied elements. 
10124         The following methods are available (default is 'average'): 
10125  
10126           * 'average': The average of the ranks that would have been assigned to 
10127             all the tied values is assigned to each value. 
10128           * 'min': The minimum of the ranks that would have been assigned to all 
10129             the tied values is assigned to each value.  (This is also 
10130             referred to as "competition" ranking.) 
10131           * 'max': The maximum of the ranks that would have been assigned to all 
10132             the tied values is assigned to each value. 
10133           * 'dense': Like 'min', but the rank of the next highest element is 
10134             assigned the rank immediately after those assigned to the tied 
10135             elements. 
10136           * 'ordinal': All values are given a distinct rank, corresponding to 
10137             the order that the values occur in `a`. 
10138     axis : {None, int}, optional 
10139         Axis along which to perform the ranking. If ``None``, the data array 
10140         is first flattened. 
10141     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'omit', 'raise'}, optional 
10142         Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 
10143         The following options are available (default is 'propagate'): 
10144  
10145           * 'propagate': propagates nans through the rank calculation 
10146           * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values 
10147           * 'raise': raises an error 
10148  
10149         .. note:: 
10150  
10151             When `nan_policy` is 'propagate', the output is an array of *all* 
10152             nans because ranks relative to nans in the input are undefined. 
10153             When `nan_policy` is 'omit', nans in `a` are ignored when ranking 
10154             the other values, and the corresponding locations of the output 
10155             are nan. 
10156  
10157         .. versionadded:: 1.10 
10158  
10159     Returns 
10160     ------- 
10161     ranks : ndarray 
10162          An array of size equal to the size of `a`, containing rank 
10163          scores. 
10164  
10165     References 
10166     ---------- 
10167     .. [1] "Ranking", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranking 
10168  
10169     Examples 
10170     -------- 
10171     >>> import numpy as np 
10172     >>> from scipy.stats import rankdata 
10173     >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2]) 
10174     array([ 1. ,  2.5,  4. ,  2.5]) 
10175     >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='min') 
10176     array([ 1,  2,  4,  2]) 
10177     >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='max') 
10178     array([ 1,  3,  4,  3]) 
10179     >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='dense') 
10180     array([ 1,  2,  3,  2]) 
10181     >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, 2], method='ordinal') 
10182     array([ 1,  2,  4,  3]) 
10183     >>> rankdata([[0, 2], [3, 2]]).reshape(2,2) 
10184     array([[1. , 2.5], 
10185           [4. , 2.5]]) 
10186     >>> rankdata([[0, 2, 2], [3, 2, 5]], axis=1) 
10187     array([[1. , 2.5, 2.5], 
10188            [2. , 1. , 3. ]]) 
10189     >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, np.nan, -2, np.nan], nan_policy="propagate") 
10190     array([nan, nan, nan, nan, nan, nan]) 
10191     >>> rankdata([0, 2, 3, np.nan, -2, np.nan], nan_policy="omit") 
10192     array([ 2.,  3.,  4., nan,  1., nan]) 
10193  
10194     """
10195     methods = ('average', 'min', 'max', 'dense', 'ordinal')
10196     if method not in methods:
10197         raise ValueError(f'unknown method "{method}"')
10198 
10199     x = np.asarray(a)
10200 
10201     if axis is None:
10202         x = x.ravel()
10203         axis = -1
10204 
10205     if x.size == 0:
10206         dtype = float if method == 'average' else np.dtype("long")
10207         return np.empty(x.shape, dtype=dtype)
10208 
10209     contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(x, nan_policy)
10210 
10211     x = np.swapaxes(x, axis, -1)
10212     ranks = _rankdata(x, method)
10213 
10214     if contains_nan:
10215         i_nan = (np.isnan(x) if nan_policy == 'omit'
10216                  else np.isnan(x).any(axis=-1))
10217         ranks = ranks.astype(float, copy=False)
10218         ranks[i_nan] = np.nan
10219 
10220     ranks = np.swapaxes(ranks, axis, -1)
10221     return ranks
10222 
10223 
10224 def _order_ranks(ranks, j):
10225     # Reorder ascending order `ranks` according to `j`
10226     ordered_ranks = np.empty(j.shape, dtype=ranks.dtype)
10227     np.put_along_axis(ordered_ranks, j, ranks, axis=-1)
10228     return ordered_ranks
10229 
10230 
10231 def _rankdata(x, method, return_ties=False):
10232     # Rank data `x` by desired `method`; `return_ties` if desired
10233     shape = x.shape
10234 
10235     # Get sort order
10236     kind = 'mergesort' if method == 'ordinal' else 'quicksort'
10237     j = np.argsort(x, axis=-1, kind=kind)
10238     ordinal_ranks = np.broadcast_to(np.arange(1, shape[-1]+1, dtype=int), shape)
10239 
10240     # Ordinal ranks is very easy because ties don't matter. We're done.
10241     if method == 'ordinal':
10242         return _order_ranks(ordinal_ranks, j)  # never return ties
10243 
10244     # Sort array
10245     y = np.take_along_axis(x, j, axis=-1)
10246     # Logical indices of unique elements
10247     i = np.concatenate([np.ones(shape[:-1] + (1,), dtype=np.bool_),
10248                        y[..., :-1] != y[..., 1:]], axis=-1)
10249 
10250     # Integer indices of unique elements
10251     indices = np.arange(y.size)[i.ravel()]
10252     # Counts of unique elements
10253     counts = np.diff(indices, append=y.size)
10254 
10255     # Compute `'min'`, `'max'`, and `'mid'` ranks of unique elements
10256     if method == 'min':
10257         ranks = ordinal_ranks[i]
10258     elif method == 'max':
10259         ranks = ordinal_ranks[i] + counts - 1
10260     elif method == 'average':
10261         ranks = ordinal_ranks[i] + (counts - 1)/2
10262     elif method == 'dense':
10263         ranks = np.cumsum(i, axis=-1)[i]
10264 
10265     ranks = np.repeat(ranks, counts).reshape(shape)
10266     ranks = _order_ranks(ranks, j)
10267 
10268     if return_ties:
10269         # Tie information is returned in a format that is useful to functions that
10270         # rely on this (private) function. Example:
10271         # >>> x = np.asarray([3, 2, 1, 2, 2, 2, 1])
10272         # >>> _, t = _rankdata(x, 'average', return_ties=True)
10273         # >>> t  # array([2., 0., 4., 0., 0., 0., 1.])  # two 1s, four 2s, and one 3
10274         # Unlike ranks, tie counts are *not* reordered to correspond with the order of
10275         # the input; e.g. the number of appearances of the lowest rank element comes
10276         # first. This is a useful format because:
10277         # - The shape of the result is the shape of the input. Different slices can
10278         #   have different numbers of tied elements but not result in a ragged array.
10279         # - Functions that use `t` usually don't need to which each element of the
10280         #   original array is associated with each tie count; they perform a reduction
10281         #   over the tie counts onnly. The tie counts are naturally computed in a
10282         #   sorted order, so this does not unnecessarily reorder them.
10283         # - One exception is `wilcoxon`, which needs the number of zeros. Zeros always
10284         #   have the lowest rank, so it is easy to find them at the zeroth index.
10285         t = np.zeros(shape, dtype=float)
10286         t[i] = counts
10287         return ranks, t
10288     return ranks
10289 
10290 
10291 def expectile(a, alpha=0.5, *, weights=None):
10292     r"""Compute the expectile at the specified level. 
10293  
10294     Expectiles are a generalization of the expectation in the same way as 
10295     quantiles are a generalization of the median. The expectile at level 
10296     `alpha = 0.5` is the mean (average). See Notes for more details. 
10297  
10298     Parameters 
10299     ---------- 
10300     a : array_like 
10301         Array containing numbers whose expectile is desired. 
10302     alpha : float, default: 0.5 
10303         The level of the expectile; e.g., ``alpha=0.5`` gives the mean. 
10304     weights : array_like, optional 
10305         An array of weights associated with the values in `a`. 
10306         The `weights` must be broadcastable to the same shape as `a`. 
10307         Default is None, which gives each value a weight of 1.0. 
10308         An integer valued weight element acts like repeating the corresponding 
10309         observation in `a` that many times. See Notes for more details. 
10310  
10311     Returns 
10312     ------- 
10313     expectile : ndarray 
10314         The empirical expectile at level `alpha`. 
10315  
10316     See Also 
10317     -------- 
10318     numpy.mean : Arithmetic average 
10319     numpy.quantile : Quantile 
10320  
10321     Notes 
10322     ----- 
10323     In general, the expectile at level :math:`\alpha` of a random variable 
10324     :math:`X` with cumulative distribution function (CDF) :math:`F` is given 
10325     by the unique solution :math:`t` of: 
10326  
10327     .. math:: 
10328  
10329         \alpha E((X - t)_+) = (1 - \alpha) E((t - X)_+) \,. 
10330  
10331     Here, :math:`(x)_+ = \max(0, x)` is the positive part of :math:`x`. 
10332     This equation can be equivalently written as: 
10333  
10334     .. math:: 
10335  
10336         \alpha \int_t^\infty (x - t)\mathrm{d}F(x) 
10337         = (1 - \alpha) \int_{-\infty}^t (t - x)\mathrm{d}F(x) \,. 
10338  
10339     The empirical expectile at level :math:`\alpha` (`alpha`) of a sample 
10340     :math:`a_i` (the array `a`) is defined by plugging in the empirical CDF of 
10341     `a`. Given sample or case weights :math:`w` (the array `weights`), it 
10342     reads :math:`F_a(x) = \frac{1}{\sum_i w_i} \sum_i w_i 1_{a_i \leq x}` 
10343     with indicator function :math:`1_{A}`. This leads to the definition of the 
10344     empirical expectile at level `alpha` as the unique solution :math:`t` of: 
10345  
10346     .. math:: 
10347  
10348         \alpha \sum_{i=1}^n w_i (a_i - t)_+ = 
10349             (1 - \alpha) \sum_{i=1}^n w_i (t - a_i)_+ \,. 
10350  
10351     For :math:`\alpha=0.5`, this simplifies to the weighted average. 
10352     Furthermore, the larger :math:`\alpha`, the larger the value of the 
10353     expectile. 
10354  
10355     As a final remark, the expectile at level :math:`\alpha` can also be 
10356     written as a minimization problem. One often used choice is 
10357  
10358     .. math:: 
10359  
10360         \operatorname{argmin}_t 
10361         E(\lvert 1_{t\geq X} - \alpha\rvert(t - X)^2) \,. 
10362  
10363     References 
10364     ---------- 
10365     .. [1] W. K. Newey and J. L. Powell (1987), "Asymmetric Least Squares 
10366            Estimation and Testing," Econometrica, 55, 819-847. 
10367     .. [2] T. Gneiting (2009). "Making and Evaluating Point Forecasts," 
10368            Journal of the American Statistical Association, 106, 746 - 762. 
10369            :doi:`10.48550/arXiv.0912.0902` 
10370  
10371     Examples 
10372     -------- 
10373     >>> import numpy as np 
10374     >>> from scipy.stats import expectile 
10375     >>> a = [1, 4, 2, -1] 
10376     >>> expectile(a, alpha=0.5) == np.mean(a) 
10377     True 
10378     >>> expectile(a, alpha=0.2) 
10379     0.42857142857142855 
10380     >>> expectile(a, alpha=0.8) 
10381     2.5714285714285716 
10382     >>> weights = [1, 3, 1, 1] 
10383  
10384     """
10385     if alpha < 0 or alpha > 1:
10386         raise ValueError(
10387             "The expectile level alpha must be in the range [0, 1]."
10388         )
10389     a = np.asarray(a)
10390 
10391     if weights is not None:
10392         weights = np.broadcast_to(weights, a.shape)
10393 
10394     # This is the empirical equivalent of Eq. (13) with identification
10395     # function from Table 9 (omitting a factor of 2) in [2] (their y is our
10396     # data a, their x is our t)
10397     def first_order(t):
10398         return np.average(np.abs((a <= t) - alpha) * (t - a), weights=weights)
10399 
10400     if alpha >= 0.5:
10401         x0 = np.average(a, weights=weights)
10402         x1 = np.amax(a)
10403     else:
10404         x1 = np.average(a, weights=weights)
10405         x0 = np.amin(a)
10406 
10407     if x0 == x1:
10408         # a has a single unique element
10409         return x0
10410 
10411     # Note that the expectile is the unique solution, so no worries about
10412     # finding a wrong root.
10413     res = root_scalar(first_order, x0=x0, x1=x1)
10414     return res.root
10415 
10416 
10417 def _lmoment_iv(sample, order, axis, sorted, standardize):
10418     # input validation/standardization for `lmoment`
10419     sample = np.asarray(sample)
10420     message = "`sample` must be an array of real numbers."
10421     if np.issubdtype(sample.dtype, np.integer):
10422         sample = sample.astype(np.float64)
10423     if not np.issubdtype(sample.dtype, np.floating):
10424         raise ValueError(message)
10425 
10426     message = "`order` must be a scalar or a non-empty array of positive integers."
10427     order = np.arange(1, 5) if order is None else np.asarray(order)
10428     if not np.issubdtype(order.dtype, np.integer) or np.any(order <= 0):
10429         raise ValueError(message)
10430 
10431     axis = np.asarray(axis)[()]
10432     message = "`axis` must be an integer."
10433     if not np.issubdtype(axis.dtype, np.integer) or axis.ndim != 0:
10434         raise ValueError(message)
10435 
10436     sorted = np.asarray(sorted)[()]
10437     message = "`sorted` must be True or False."
10438     if not np.issubdtype(sorted.dtype, np.bool_) or sorted.ndim != 0:
10439         raise ValueError(message)
10440 
10441     standardize = np.asarray(standardize)[()]
10442     message = "`standardize` must be True or False."
10443     if not np.issubdtype(standardize.dtype, np.bool_) or standardize.ndim != 0:
10444         raise ValueError(message)
10445 
10446     sample = np.moveaxis(sample, axis, -1)
10447     sample = np.sort(sample, axis=-1) if not sorted else sample
10448 
10449     return sample, order, axis, sorted, standardize
10450 
10451 
10452 def _br(x, *, r=0):
10453     n = x.shape[-1]
10454     x = np.expand_dims(x, axis=-2)
10455     x = np.broadcast_to(x, x.shape[:-2] + (len(r), n))
10456     x = np.triu(x)
10457     j = np.arange(n, dtype=x.dtype)
10458     n = np.asarray(n, dtype=x.dtype)[()]
10459     return (np.sum(special.binom(j, r[:, np.newaxis])*x, axis=-1)
10460             / special.binom(n-1, r) / n)
10461 
10462 
10463 def _prk(r, k):
10464     # Writen to match [1] Equation 27 closely to facilitate review.
10465     # This does not protect against overflow, so improvements to
10466     # robustness would be a welcome follow-up.
10467     return (-1)**(r-k)*special.binom(r, k)*special.binom(r+k, k)
10468 
10469 
10470 @_axis_nan_policy_factory(  # noqa: E302
10471     _moment_result_object, n_samples=1, result_to_tuple=_moment_tuple,
10472     n_outputs=lambda kwds: _moment_outputs(kwds, [1, 2, 3, 4])
10473 )
10474 def lmoment(sample, order=None, *, axis=0, sorted=False, standardize=True):
10475     r"""Compute L-moments of a sample from a continuous distribution 
10476  
10477     The L-moments of a probability distribution are summary statistics with 
10478     uses similar to those of conventional moments, but they are defined in 
10479     terms of the expected values of order statistics. 
10480     Sample L-moments are defined analogously to population L-moments, and 
10481     they can serve as estimators of population L-moments. They tend to be less 
10482     sensitive to extreme observations than conventional moments. 
10483  
10484     Parameters 
10485     ---------- 
10486     sample : array_like 
10487         The real-valued sample whose L-moments are desired. 
10488     order : array_like, optional 
10489         The (positive integer) orders of the desired L-moments. 
10490         Must be a scalar or non-empty 1D array. Default is [1, 2, 3, 4]. 
10491     axis : int or None, default=0 
10492         If an int, the axis of the input along which to compute the statistic. 
10493         The statistic of each axis-slice (e.g. row) of the input will appear 
10494         in a corresponding element of the output. If None, the input will be 
10495         raveled before computing the statistic. 
10496     sorted : bool, default=False 
10497         Whether `sample` is already sorted in increasing order along `axis`. 
10498         If False (default), `sample` will be sorted. 
10499     standardize : bool, default=True 
10500         Whether to return L-moment ratios for orders 3 and higher. 
10501         L-moment ratios are analogous to standardized conventional 
10502         moments: they are the non-standardized L-moments divided 
10503         by the L-moment of order 2. 
10504  
10505     Returns 
10506     ------- 
10507     lmoments : ndarray 
10508         The sample L-moments of order `order`. 
10509  
10510     See Also 
10511     -------- 
10512     moment 
10513  
10514     References 
10515     ---------- 
10516     .. [1] D. Bilkova. "L-Moments and TL-Moments as an Alternative Tool of 
10517            Statistical Data Analysis". Journal of Applied Mathematics and 
10518            Physics. 2014. :doi:`10.4236/jamp.2014.210104` 
10519     .. [2] J. R. M. Hosking. "L-Moments: Analysis and Estimation of Distributions 
10520            Using Linear Combinations of Order Statistics". Journal of the Royal 
10521            Statistical Society. 1990. :doi:`10.1111/j.2517-6161.1990.tb01775.x` 
10522     .. [3] "L-moment". *Wikipedia*. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L-moment. 
10523  
10524     Examples 
10525     -------- 
10526     >>> import numpy as np 
10527     >>> from scipy import stats 
10528     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng(328458568356392) 
10529     >>> sample = rng.exponential(size=100000) 
10530     >>> stats.lmoment(sample) 
10531     array([1.00124272, 0.50111437, 0.3340092 , 0.16755338]) 
10532  
10533     Note that the first four standardized population L-moments of the standard 
10534     exponential distribution are 1, 1/2, 1/3, and 1/6; the sample L-moments 
10535     provide reasonable estimates. 
10536  
10537     """
10538     args = _lmoment_iv(sample, order, axis, sorted, standardize)
10539     sample, order, axis, sorted, standardize = args
10540 
10541     n_moments = np.max(order)
10542     k = np.arange(n_moments, dtype=sample.dtype)
10543     prk = _prk(np.expand_dims(k, tuple(range(1, sample.ndim+1))), k)
10544     bk = _br(sample, r=k)
10545 
10546     n = sample.shape[-1]
10547     bk[..., n:] = 0  # remove NaNs due to n_moments > n
10548 
10549     lmoms = np.sum(prk * bk, axis=-1)
10550     if standardize and n_moments > 2:
10551         lmoms[2:] /= lmoms[1]
10552 
10553     lmoms[n:] = np.nan  # add NaNs where appropriate
10554     return lmoms[order-1]
10555 
10556 
10557 LinregressResult = _make_tuple_bunch('LinregressResult',
10558                                      ['slope', 'intercept', 'rvalue',
10559                                       'pvalue', 'stderr'],
10560                                      extra_field_names=['intercept_stderr'])
10561 
10562 
10563 def linregress(x, y=None, alternative='two-sided'):
10564     """ 
10565     Calculate a linear least-squares regression for two sets of measurements. 
10566  
10567     Parameters 
10568     ---------- 
10569     x, y : array_like 
10570         Two sets of measurements.  Both arrays should have the same length N.  If 
10571         only `x` is given (and ``y=None``), then it must be a two-dimensional 
10572         array where one dimension has length 2.  The two sets of measurements 
10573         are then found by splitting the array along the length-2 dimension. In 
10574         the case where ``y=None`` and `x` is a 2xN array, ``linregress(x)`` is 
10575         equivalent to ``linregress(x[0], x[1])``. 
10576  
10577         .. deprecated:: 1.14.0 
10578             Inference of the two sets of measurements from a single argument `x` 
10579             is deprecated will result in an error in SciPy 1.16.0; the sets 
10580             must be specified separately as `x` and `y`. 
10581     alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional 
10582         Defines the alternative hypothesis. Default is 'two-sided'. 
10583         The following options are available: 
10584  
10585         * 'two-sided': the slope of the regression line is nonzero 
10586         * 'less': the slope of the regression line is less than zero 
10587         * 'greater':  the slope of the regression line is greater than zero 
10588  
10589         .. versionadded:: 1.7.0 
10590  
10591     Returns 
10592     ------- 
10593     result : ``LinregressResult`` instance 
10594         The return value is an object with the following attributes: 
10595  
10596         slope : float 
10597             Slope of the regression line. 
10598         intercept : float 
10599             Intercept of the regression line. 
10600         rvalue : float 
10601             The Pearson correlation coefficient. The square of ``rvalue`` 
10602             is equal to the coefficient of determination. 
10603         pvalue : float 
10604             The p-value for a hypothesis test whose null hypothesis is 
10605             that the slope is zero, using Wald Test with t-distribution of 
10606             the test statistic. See `alternative` above for alternative 
10607             hypotheses. 
10608         stderr : float 
10609             Standard error of the estimated slope (gradient), under the 
10610             assumption of residual normality. 
10611         intercept_stderr : float 
10612             Standard error of the estimated intercept, under the assumption 
10613             of residual normality. 
10614  
10615     See Also 
10616     -------- 
10617     scipy.optimize.curve_fit : 
10618         Use non-linear least squares to fit a function to data. 
10619     scipy.optimize.leastsq : 
10620         Minimize the sum of squares of a set of equations. 
10621  
10622     Notes 
10623     ----- 
10624     For compatibility with older versions of SciPy, the return value acts 
10625     like a ``namedtuple`` of length 5, with fields ``slope``, ``intercept``, 
10626     ``rvalue``, ``pvalue`` and ``stderr``, so one can continue to write:: 
10627  
10628         slope, intercept, r, p, se = linregress(x, y) 
10629  
10630     With that style, however, the standard error of the intercept is not 
10631     available.  To have access to all the computed values, including the 
10632     standard error of the intercept, use the return value as an object 
10633     with attributes, e.g.:: 
10634  
10635         result = linregress(x, y) 
10636         print(result.intercept, result.intercept_stderr) 
10637  
10638     Examples 
10639     -------- 
10640     >>> import numpy as np 
10641     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
10642     >>> from scipy import stats 
10643     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng() 
10644  
10645     Generate some data: 
10646  
10647     >>> x = rng.random(10) 
10648     >>> y = 1.6*x + rng.random(10) 
10649  
10650     Perform the linear regression: 
10651  
10652     >>> res = stats.linregress(x, y) 
10653  
10654     Coefficient of determination (R-squared): 
10655  
10656     >>> print(f"R-squared: {res.rvalue**2:.6f}") 
10657     R-squared: 0.717533 
10658  
10659     Plot the data along with the fitted line: 
10660  
10661     >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'o', label='original data') 
10662     >>> plt.plot(x, res.intercept + res.slope*x, 'r', label='fitted line') 
10663     >>> plt.legend() 
10664     >>> plt.show() 
10665  
10666     Calculate 95% confidence interval on slope and intercept: 
10667  
10668     >>> # Two-sided inverse Students t-distribution 
10669     >>> # p - probability, df - degrees of freedom 
10670     >>> from scipy.stats import t 
10671     >>> tinv = lambda p, df: abs(t.ppf(p/2, df)) 
10672  
10673     >>> ts = tinv(0.05, len(x)-2) 
10674     >>> print(f"slope (95%): {res.slope:.6f} +/- {ts*res.stderr:.6f}") 
10675     slope (95%): 1.453392 +/- 0.743465 
10676     >>> print(f"intercept (95%): {res.intercept:.6f}" 
10677     ...       f" +/- {ts*res.intercept_stderr:.6f}") 
10678     intercept (95%): 0.616950 +/- 0.544475 
10679  
10680     """
10681     TINY = 1.0e-20
10682     if y is None:  # x is a (2, N) or (N, 2) shaped array_like
10683         message = ('Inference of the two sets of measurements from a single "'
10684                    'argument `x` is deprecated will result in an error in "'
10685                    'SciPy 1.16.0; the sets must be specified separately as "'
10686                    '`x` and `y`.')
10687         warnings.warn(message, DeprecationWarning, stacklevel=2)
10688         x = np.asarray(x)
10689         if x.shape[0] == 2:
10690             x, y = x
10691         elif x.shape[1] == 2:
10692             x, y = x.T
10693         else:
10694             raise ValueError("If only `x` is given as input, it has to "
10695                              "be of shape (2, N) or (N, 2); provided shape "
10696                              f"was {x.shape}.")
10697     else:
10698         x = np.asarray(x)
10699         y = np.asarray(y)
10700 
10701     if x.size == 0 or y.size == 0:
10702         raise ValueError("Inputs must not be empty.")
10703 
10704     if np.amax(x) == np.amin(x) and len(x) > 1:
10705         raise ValueError("Cannot calculate a linear regression "
10706                          "if all x values are identical")
10707 
10708     n = len(x)
10709     xmean = np.mean(x, None)
10710     ymean = np.mean(y, None)
10711 
10712     # Average sums of square differences from the mean
10713     #   ssxm = mean( (x-mean(x))^2 )
10714     #   ssxym = mean( (x-mean(x)) * (y-mean(y)) )
10715     ssxm, ssxym, _, ssym = np.cov(x, y, bias=1).flat
10716 
10717     # R-value
10718     #   r = ssxym / sqrt( ssxm * ssym )
10719     if ssxm == 0.0 or ssym == 0.0:
10720         # If the denominator was going to be 0
10721         r = 0.0
10722     else:
10723         r = ssxym / np.sqrt(ssxm * ssym)
10724         # Test for numerical error propagation (make sure -1 < r < 1)
10725         if r > 1.0:
10726             r = 1.0
10727         elif r < -1.0:
10728             r = -1.0
10729 
10730     slope = ssxym / ssxm
10731     intercept = ymean - slope*xmean
10732     if n == 2:
10733         # handle case when only two points are passed in
10734         if y[0] == y[1]:
10735             prob = 1.0
10736         else:
10737             prob = 0.0
10738         slope_stderr = 0.0
10739         intercept_stderr = 0.0
10740     else:
10741         df = n - 2  # Number of degrees of freedom
10742         # n-2 degrees of freedom because 2 has been used up
10743         # to estimate the mean and standard deviation
10744         t = r * np.sqrt(df / ((1.0 - r + TINY)*(1.0 + r + TINY)))
10745 
10746         dist = _SimpleStudentT(df)
10747         prob = _get_pvalue(t, dist, alternative, xp=np)
10748         prob = prob[()] if prob.ndim == 0 else prob
10749 
10750         slope_stderr = np.sqrt((1 - r**2) * ssym / ssxm / df)
10751 
10752         # Also calculate the standard error of the intercept
10753         # The following relationship is used:
10754         #   ssxm = mean( (x-mean(x))^2 )
10755         #        = ssx - sx*sx
10756         #        = mean( x^2 ) - mean(x)^2
10757         intercept_stderr = slope_stderr * np.sqrt(ssxm + xmean**2)
10758 
10759     return LinregressResult(slope=slope, intercept=intercept, rvalue=r,
10760                             pvalue=prob, stderr=slope_stderr,
10761                             intercept_stderr=intercept_stderr)
10762 
10763 
10764 def _xp_mean(x, /, *, axis=None, weights=None, keepdims=False, nan_policy='propagate',
10765              dtype=None, xp=None):
10766     r"""Compute the arithmetic mean along the specified axis. 
10767  
10768     Parameters 
10769     ---------- 
10770     x : real array 
10771         Array containing real numbers whose mean is desired. 
10772     axis : int or tuple of ints, default: None 
10773         If an int or tuple of ints, the axis or axes of the input along which 
10774         to compute the statistic. The statistic of each axis-slice (e.g. row) 
10775         of the input will appear in a corresponding element of the output. 
10776         If ``None``, the input will be raveled before computing the statistic. 
10777     weights : real array, optional 
10778         If specified, an array of weights associated with the values in `x`; 
10779         otherwise ``1``. If `weights` and `x` do not have the same shape, the 
10780         arrays will be broadcasted before performing the calculation. See 
10781         Notes for details. 
10782     keepdims : boolean, optional 
10783         If this is set to ``True``, the axes which are reduced are left 
10784         in the result as dimensions with length one. With this option, 
10785         the result will broadcast correctly against the input array. 
10786     nan_policy : {'propagate', 'omit', 'raise'}, default: 'propagate' 
10787         Defines how to handle input NaNs. 
10788  
10789         - ``propagate``: if a NaN is present in the axis slice (e.g. row) along 
10790           which the statistic is computed, the corresponding entry of the output 
10791           will be NaN. 
10792         - ``omit``: NaNs will be omitted when performing the calculation. 
10793           If insufficient data remains in the axis slice along which the 
10794           statistic is computed, the corresponding entry of the output will be 
10795           NaN. 
10796         - ``raise``: if a NaN is present, a ``ValueError`` will be raised. 
10797  
10798     dtype : dtype, optional 
10799         Type to use in computing the mean. For integer inputs, the default is 
10800         the default float type of the array library; for floating point inputs, 
10801         the dtype is that of the input. 
10802  
10803     Returns 
10804     ------- 
10805     out : array 
10806         The mean of each slice 
10807  
10808     Notes 
10809     ----- 
10810     Let :math:`x_i` represent element :math:`i` of data `x` and let :math:`w_i` 
10811     represent the corresponding element of `weights` after broadcasting. Then the 
10812     (weighted) mean :math:`\bar{x}_w` is given by: 
10813  
10814     .. math:: 
10815  
10816         \bar{x}_w = \frac{ \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} w_i x_i } 
10817                          { \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} w_i } 
10818  
10819     where :math:`n` is the number of elements along a slice. Note that this simplifies 
10820     to the familiar :math:`(\sum_i x_i) / n` when the weights are all ``1`` (default). 
10821  
10822     The behavior of this function with respect to weights is somewhat different 
10823     from that of `np.average`. For instance, 
10824     `np.average` raises an error when `axis` is not specified and the shapes of `x` 
10825     and the `weights` array are not the same; `xp_mean` simply broadcasts the two. 
10826     Also, `np.average` raises an error when weights sum to zero along a slice; 
10827     `xp_mean` computes the appropriate result. The intent is for this function's 
10828     interface to be consistent with the rest of `scipy.stats`. 
10829  
10830     Note that according to the formula, including NaNs with zero weights is not 
10831     the same as *omitting* NaNs with ``nan_policy='omit'``; in the former case, 
10832     the NaNs will continue to propagate through the calculation whereas in the 
10833     latter case, the NaNs are excluded entirely. 
10834  
10835     """
10836     # ensure that `x` and `weights` are array-API compatible arrays of identical shape
10837     xp = array_namespace(x) if xp is None else xp
10838     x = _asarray(x, dtype=dtype, subok=True)
10839     weights = xp.asarray(weights, dtype=dtype) if weights is not None else weights
10840 
10841     # to ensure that this matches the behavior of decorated functions when one of the
10842     # arguments has size zero, it's easiest to call a similar decorated function.
10843     if is_numpy(xp) and (xp_size(x) == 0
10844                          or (weights is not None and xp_size(weights) == 0)):
10845         return gmean(x, weights=weights, axis=axis, keepdims=keepdims)
10846 
10847     x, weights = xp_broadcast_promote(x, weights, force_floating=True)
10848 
10849     # handle the special case of zero-sized arrays
10850     message = (too_small_1d_not_omit if (x.ndim == 1 or axis is None)
10851                else too_small_nd_not_omit)
10852     if xp_size(x) == 0:
10853         with warnings.catch_warnings():
10854             warnings.simplefilter("ignore")
10855             res = xp.mean(x, axis=axis, keepdims=keepdims)
10856         if xp_size(res) != 0:
10857             warnings.warn(message, SmallSampleWarning, stacklevel=2)
10858         return res
10859 
10860     contains_nan, _ = _contains_nan(x, nan_policy, xp_omit_okay=True, xp=xp)
10861     if weights is not None:
10862         contains_nan_w, _ = _contains_nan(weights, nan_policy, xp_omit_okay=True, xp=xp)
10863         contains_nan = contains_nan | contains_nan_w
10864 
10865     # Handle `nan_policy='omit'` by giving zero weight to NaNs, whether they
10866     # appear in `x` or `weights`. Emit warning if there is an all-NaN slice.
10867     message = (too_small_1d_omit if (x.ndim == 1 or axis is None)
10868                else too_small_nd_omit)
10869     if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
10870         nan_mask = xp.isnan(x)
10871         if weights is not None:
10872             nan_mask |= xp.isnan(weights)
10873         if xp.any(xp.all(nan_mask, axis=axis)):
10874             warnings.warn(message, SmallSampleWarning, stacklevel=2)
10875         weights = xp.ones_like(x) if weights is None else weights
10876         x = xp.where(nan_mask, xp.asarray(0, dtype=x.dtype), x)
10877         weights = xp.where(nan_mask, xp.asarray(0, dtype=x.dtype), weights)
10878 
10879     # Perform the mean calculation itself
10880     if weights is None:
10881         return xp.mean(x, axis=axis, keepdims=keepdims)
10882 
10883     norm = xp.sum(weights, axis=axis)
10884     wsum = xp.sum(x * weights, axis=axis)
10885     with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
10886         res = wsum/norm
10887 
10888     # Respect `keepdims` and convert NumPy 0-D arrays to scalars
10889     if keepdims:
10890 
10891         if axis is None:
10892             final_shape = (1,) * len(x.shape)
10893         else:
10894             # axis can be a scalar or sequence
10895             axes = (axis,) if not isinstance(axis, Sequence) else axis
10896             final_shape = list(x.shape)
10897             for i in axes:
10898                 final_shape[i] = 1
10899 
10900         res = xp.reshape(res, final_shape)
10901 
10902     return res[()] if res.ndim == 0 else res
10903 
10904 
10905 def _xp_var(x, /, *, axis=None, correction=0, keepdims=False, nan_policy='propagate',
10906             dtype=None, xp=None):
10907     # an array-api compatible function for variance with scipy.stats interface
10908     # and features (e.g. `nan_policy`).
10909     xp = array_namespace(x) if xp is None else xp
10910     x = _asarray(x, subok=True)
10911 
10912     # use `_xp_mean` instead of `xp.var` for desired warning behavior
10913     # it would be nice to combine this with `_var`, which uses `_moment`
10914     # and therefore warns when precision is lost, but that does not support
10915     # `axis` tuples or keepdims. Eventually, `_axis_nan_policy` will simplify
10916     # `axis` tuples and implement `keepdims` for non-NumPy arrays; then it will
10917     # be easy.
10918     kwargs = dict(axis=axis, nan_policy=nan_policy, dtype=dtype, xp=xp)
10919     mean = _xp_mean(x, keepdims=True, **kwargs)
10920     x = _asarray(x, dtype=mean.dtype, subok=True)
10921     x_mean = _demean(x, mean, axis, xp=xp)
10922     x_mean_conj = (xp.conj(x_mean) if xp.isdtype(x_mean.dtype, 'complex floating')
10923                    else x_mean)  # crossref data-apis/array-api#824
10924     var = _xp_mean(x_mean * x_mean_conj, keepdims=keepdims, **kwargs)
10925 
10926     if correction != 0:
10927         if axis is None:
10928             n = xp_size(x)
10929         elif np.iterable(axis):  # note: using NumPy on `axis` is OK
10930             n = math.prod(x.shape[i] for i in axis)
10931         else:
10932             n = x.shape[axis]
10933         # Or two lines with ternaries : )
10934         # axis = range(x.ndim) if axis is None else axis
10935         # n = math.prod(x.shape[i] for i in axis) if iterable(axis) else x.shape[axis]
10936 
10937         n = xp.asarray(n, dtype=var.dtype)
10938 
10939         if nan_policy == 'omit':
10940             nan_mask = xp.astype(xp.isnan(x), var.dtype)
10941             n = n - xp.sum(nan_mask, axis=axis, keepdims=keepdims)
10942 
10943         # Produce NaNs silently when n - correction <= 0
10944         factor = _lazywhere(n-correction > 0, (n, n-correction), xp.divide, xp.nan)
10945         var *= factor
10946 
10947     return var[()] if var.ndim == 0 else var
10948 
10949 
10950 class _SimpleNormal:
10951     # A very simple, array-API compatible normal distribution for use in
10952     # hypothesis tests. May be replaced by new infrastructure Normal
10953     # distribution in due time.
10954 
10955     def cdf(self, x):
10956         return special.ndtr(x)
10957 
10958     def sf(self, x):
10959         return special.ndtr(-x)
10960 
10961     def isf(self, x):
10962         return -special.ndtri(x)
10963 
10964 
10965 class _SimpleChi2:
10966     # A very simple, array-API compatible chi-squared distribution for use in
10967     # hypothesis tests. May be replaced by new infrastructure chi-squared
10968     # distribution in due time.
10969     def __init__(self, df):
10970         self.df = df
10971 
10972     def cdf(self, x):
10973         return special.chdtr(self.df, x)
10974 
10975     def sf(self, x):
10976         return special.chdtrc(self.df, x)
10977 
10978 
10979 class _SimpleBeta:
10980     # A very simple, array-API compatible beta distribution for use in
10981     # hypothesis tests. May be replaced by new infrastructure beta
10982     # distribution in due time.
10983     def __init__(self, a, b, *, loc=None, scale=None):
10984         self.a = a
10985         self.b = b
10986         self.loc = loc
10987         self.scale = scale
10988 
10989     def cdf(self, x):
10990         if self.loc is not None or self.scale is not None:
10991             loc = 0 if self.loc is None else self.loc
10992             scale = 1 if self.scale is None else self.scale
10993             return special.betainc(self.a, self.b, (x - loc)/scale)
10994         return special.betainc(self.a, self.b, x)
10995 
10996     def sf(self, x):
10997         if self.loc is not None or self.scale is not None:
10998             loc = 0 if self.loc is None else self.loc
10999             scale = 1 if self.scale is None else self.scale
11000             return special.betaincc(self.a, self.b, (x - loc)/scale)
11001         return special.betaincc(self.a, self.b, x)
11002 
11003 
11004 class _SimpleStudentT:
11005     # A very simple, array-API compatible t distribution for use in
11006     # hypothesis tests. May be replaced by new infrastructure t
11007     # distribution in due time.
11008     def __init__(self, df):
11009         self.df = df
11010 
11011     def cdf(self, t):
11012         return special.stdtr(self.df, t)
11013 
11014     def sf(self, t):
11015         return special.stdtr(self.df, -t)
11016
